rows.title: Master strategist, warrior and negotiator in 1700s Africa. And a woman. Hear more about Queen Njinga of Angola on Thursday
keywords: mariners' museum and park newport news
rows.prologue: Boston University professor Linda Heywood will discuss her book "Njinga of Angola, Africa's Warrior Queen" Thursday at the Mariners' Museum and Park in Newport News. Njinga ruled during the 1600s and the first Africans to land in Virginia came from her kingdom.
content: This African leader was a feared negotiator, highly influential among European heads of state in the 17th century. The ferocious commander led troops into battle well into old age.
This leader was also a woman, Queen Njinga of present-day Angola. She will be the lecture topic at The Mariners’ Museum and Park on Thursday.

Linda Heywood, a Boston University professor of African American Studies and History, wrote the book “Njinga of Angola: Africa’s Warrior Queen” earlier this year. The first Africans brought to an English colony in North America landed in Hampton and were Njinga’s people.

Heywood spent a decade traveling to various countries to examine more than 10,000 resources to tell of Njinga, the rare female leader who defended her country for decades from being taken over by the Portuguese and neighboring African invaders. She maneuvered European politics and religion to make it happen.
Heywood puts Njinga in the category of European women leaders like Queen Elizabeth I, who ruled over a period of peace and prosperity in England in the 1500s.
“But Queen Victoria did not lead an army,” Heywood said during a phone interview.
Njinga Mbandi (Njinga is pronounced Jenga) was born in 1582 into the royal family.
She was born at a time when British, French and Portuguese slave traders were vying for human cargo and territory along Africa’s west coast.
Portugal had seized land near Ndongo. With this threat, the king at the time, Njinga’s brother, sent his sister to negotiate.
Heywood said there was sibling rivalry, but Njinga was known to be the smarter of the duo. She had fought alongside her father when he was king and sat at his feet when he held court.

During the meeting with the Portuguese governor in 1622, the leader instructed Njinga to sit on a rug while he took a seat in a chair. Njinga motioned to a servant who got down on all fours forming a chair for Njinga.

Heywood said that as mean as that might sound, Njinga was not going to be cowered, and her entourage understood that. The leaders negotiated a truce. With the death of her brother two years later, Njinga assumed the kingdom’s leadership.

During the next decades, Njinga fought constantly with the Portuguese, losing her throne for a few years, then eventually getting the government to recognize her authority. She converted to Christianity at one point, only because she knew it could help as she worked with other powers, including the Vatican and the Dutch.
“The survival of her state would only come if she had relationships with the papacy,” Heywood said. “That’s what I called spiritual diplomacy.”
Njinga would outlive 11 Portuguese governors; she ruled until her death in 1663. She was 81 and considered a god for living and thriving at such an age.
“When I started the project I said, ‘Njinga, tell me the truth about you,’ ” Heywood said. “I hope that I got as close to the truth as I could.”

rows.title: A proliferation of panhandling in Chesapeake may lead to greater regulations
rows.prologue: Violators could be ordered to do community service or fined up to $200 for pedestrians and $350 for drivers.
content: CHESAPEAKE
The City Council could vote Tuesday on a proposed law meant to quash what some members call a recent proliferation of panhandling.
Citing risks to drivers and pedestrians, council members said the bill is about public safety.
“It’s such an accident hazard,” Councilwoman Ella Ward said.

The ordinance includes a ban on cars stopping at green lights, unless it’s to yield to another car or a crossing pedestrian. It also makes it illegal to “stand, sit, squat or lie in between motor vehicle traffic lanes on any public right of way” when there are four or more lanes or where the posted speed limit is 35 mph or higher. That clause would not apply to people legally crossing the street, emergency personnel or supervised inmates mowing or doing ditch maintenance, among other exceptions.

An alternate version could include rules covering curbs and gutters, but not sidewalks or pedestrian trails, according to City Attorney Jan Proctor. Violators could be ordered to do community service or fined up to $200 for pedestrians and $350 for drivers.

It’s not specifically a panhandling ordinance, Mayor Rick West said. But he and some other council members say there’s been an increase in panhandling over the past six months in areas including Grassfield, Chesapeake Square and Edinburgh.
Councilman Roland Davis, who lives in Greenbrier, said it’s prevalent at intersections there and near other shopping centers .
Until recently, it was illegal to beg on city streets in Chesapeake.
Police Chief Kelvin Wright said Proctor told him about six months ago that that ordinance was unconstitutional.
That made it unenforceable . And that has led to an increase in panhandling – and complaints about it, Wright said.

Governing.com, a website that writes about state and local government, said in July that changes like the one Chesapeake is considering may be an unintended consequence of a 2015 U.S. Supreme Court decision that said “content-based” restrictions on signs violate the First Amendment.
The City Council recently passed its first phase of a sign ordinance update because of that ruling.
Chesapeake’s law related to begging was repealed in late June.
Proctor said by email that it was deemed a content-based ordinance that could limit the First Amendment right to free speech.
Some neighboring cities address panhandling; in Virginia Beach, for example, it’s a Class 4 misdemeanor to beg on city streets or beaches.

In March 2016, Suffolk changed its regulations to prohibit panhandling on medians and shoulders and within 15 feet of more than 20 thoroughfares in high-density areas after a surge of panhandlers in the northern part of the city.

“In order to limit expressive conduct in public streets, governmental restrictions must be content neutral or be subject to strict scrutiny under the Constitution, which is a very difficult burden of proof to meet,” Proctor said in an email. “If the ordinance were to distinguish on the basis of the reason a person is standing, sitting, squatting or lying in the prohibited areas of right-of-way, the ordinance would more likely be found unconstitutional.”
If approved, the ordinance could provide a tool to deal not only with the people asking for handouts, but also with the drivers providing the handouts, Wright said. .
“It is a traffic safety concern as well,” Wright said, adding the locations that panhandlers find appealing tend to be the city’s major intersections. “You want traffic to freely flow.”

Although there’s no public hearing on the proposed changes, residents can address them during “citizen comments on agenda items” at tonight’s meeting, which starts at 6:30 . at City Hall. If the council approves the ordinance, it will become law in 30 days – unless it’s passed as an emergency measure, which would be effective immediately.
West said some worthy causes could also be adversely affected as a result of the changes, and Ward said the goal is public safety, not punishment.
If the bill becomes law, Wright said, officers will provide warnings to people found begging and suggest ways for them to get help.
The preference is compliance over enforcement, he said.
“I believe things will probably return to the way it was under the old ordinance,” Wright said.

rows.title: Letter: Two-party system is failing America
content: NO PARTY SYSTEM governed the appointees who drafted the Articles of Confederation, our Declaration of Independence and our Constitution. How did these remarkable documents ever get written, ratified and implemented?

One reason for each: The interest of the colonies were at heart, not party loyalty or personal political careers. These documents were designed to provide self-directed government by the people — not speakers, committees, conferences or caucuses.
Those representatives, cantankerous at times, were determined to complete their appointed duty and get back home. They would assemble again when there was a need.

They were not gathered at Independence Hall in Philadelphia with an eye on creating permanent political jobs that the two-party system fosters. In my opinion, the party System gets in the way, creates “good ole boy” selected candidates for political office and keeps them there even when the people think it’s time for them to go.

There should be no place in our national government for tenured senators and representatives, kept in place by the two-party system. Why can’t Mr. Smith go to Washington anymore? America should be a republic governed by the people. Instead, the two-party system governs us.

It is time, as financially impractical as it seems, for the common men and women in our communities, who have had enough of legislative vacationers, to rise up and become a political force of non-party candidates in love with our constitutional republic, and to start a grassroots renaissance of the American dream and drive all politicians out of office who have labored to preserve themselves rather than making America great again.
It’s time to raise the banners and play the fanfare for the common man. It’s time to take back America from the political elites of the two-party system.
Ronald Liston
Chesapeake

rows.title: Letter: Don't tax students to help corporate America
content: I hope all students and their families are paying close attention to the proposed new federal tax law, one component of which could seriously undermine opportunities for higher education.

The legislation passed by the House of Representatives would do away with tax-exempt tuition and fee remissions for graduate students, meaning that tuition and fees for students in graduate roles would become taxable income.

These tuition and fee waivers are simply that — waivers — with no actual money going into students’ pockets. So students will be taxed on the value of the tuition they would have paid, which for even public universities can easily be $30,000 to $40,000 a year.

Graduate students will be expected to pay thousands of dollars on money they were not given. Graduate students represent the future of research and scholarship, and this provision will effectively eliminate the opportunity for many students to complete their studies.

A Nov. 16 New York Times article outlines the devastating effect the repeal of Section 117(d)(5) of the current tax codes would have on the future of higher education. This change in the law appears to be not only another way of putting more tax burden on the little guy (death by a thousand cuts), but also the growing animosity among some conservatives toward education, which is seen as elitist.
Let’s hope the bill that is ultimately approved does not try to fill the hole created by cutting taxes on corporate America by loading new taxes on students, as the House version does.
Alice Allen-Grimes
Norfolk

rows.title: Letter: Poor will pay for tax breaks for the rich
content: It’s clear who will benefit from the new tax plan in Washington: the rich. What we’re hearing less about is who will pay the consequences, and that’s hardworking, low-income Americans such as my family.

I grew up in poverty. I know what it is like to go hungry, to not have access to medical care, and to not have basic necessities like running water or heat in the winter time. People who are living right now like I did as a child depend on programs such as SNAP and Medicaid to survive.

This year we’ve already seen attempts to gut those essential programs. So after giving away $1.5 trillion in tax breaks to millionaires, Medicaid and SNAP and other anti-poverty programs will likely wind up back on the chopping block.

With one in eight Americans below the poverty line, this is both bad public policy and just plain wrong. I hope we can count on Sens. Mark Warner and Tim Kaine to stand up against this plan. They should work to strengthen effective anti-poverty policies so low-income Virginians do not end up hungry and in the dark like I was.
Golden Carter
Virginia Beach

rows.title: Letter: Federal judges shouldn't be free to make stupid decisions
content: U.S. federal judges are appointed for life, but that fact alone does not entitle them to make stupid decisions.
A case in point is President Donald Trump’s foreign travel ban, which a federal judge ruled unconstitutional. The decision was recently overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court.
Federal judges that have been overturned three times on issues that have a political bias should have to be reconfirmed by the U.S. Senate — a three strikes and you are out policy.
They also should be required to read the U.S. Constitution. It would stop the waste and abuse caused by these ridiculous decisions.
Theodore D. Galanides
Virginia Beach

rows.title: Editorial: Savage, Brock left their mark on the region
content: “THE PURPOSE of life is not to be happy at all,” the American author and humorist Leo Rosten wrote. “It is to be useful, to be honorable. It is to be compassionate. It is to matter, to have it make some difference that you lived.”

The noble intent there described by Rosten seems particularly apt when considering the lives of Toy D. Savage Jr. and Macon Brock, two significant, influential and beloved members of this community who died in recent days.
If judged by professional achievements alone, both men would be considered tremendously successful.

Savage, who died on Thursday at the age of 96, was a partner for almost 70 years at the Norfolk legal firm Willcox Savage. An adept practitioner of the law, Savage was the former president of the Virginia Bar Association, an adjunct professor at the College of William and Mary Law School, and a lecturer at William and Mary, the University of Virginia and New York University.

Brock, who was 75 years old when he died on Saturday, was a co-founder and CEO of the Chesapeake-based discount retail chain Dollar Tree. That well known and much loved empire, which began with just five stores in 1986, now boasts more than 5,000 locations.
However, to tell their stories is to look beyond the boardroom and the courtroom.

Both men served in the armed forces — Savage in the U.S. Navy during World War II and Brock in the U.S. Marine Corps during the Vietnam War — and the qualities gleaned from those experiences helped shape their approach to civic affairs.
Not content to sit on the sidelines, both men felt an obligation to improve this community, and to repay their good fortune through public service.

For Savage, that meant spending 38 years on the board of the Hampton Roads Community Foundation, including five as the chair; 10 years in the House of Delegates; and nine years on the Governor’s Advisory Board on Industrial Development.

His obituary in the Pilot notes his devotion to improving health care in the region, which saw him spend 54 years as a director of Sentara Healthcare, including two years as president, and in other notable community causes. He was honored in 1980 as Norfolk’s First Citizen.

For Brock, success in business afforded him the chance to focus on higher education and environmental stewardship, two areas which benefited greatly from his time and his generosity. He served on the Hampton Roads Community Foundation Board of Directors and spent 10 years as chair of the Randolph-Macon Board of Trustees.

He and his wife Joan were honored in 2015 with the national Outstanding Philanthropist award presented by the Association of Fundraising Professionals for their history of giving. At the time, they had given more than $40 million to charitable causes, much of it benefiting Hampton Roads.

Among other facilities, the Brocks are responsible for helping build the Chesapeake Bay Foundation’s Brock Environmental Center, the M. Foscue Brock Institute for Community and Global Health at Eastern Virginia Medical School and the Brock Commons outdoor amphitheater at Old Dominion University.

They endowed the curator of American art position at the Chrysler Museum of Art, assisted ACCESS College Foundation programs and supported the United Way of South Hampton Roads’ United for Children program.
To family and friends, the loss of these two men is surely difficult and emotional. Their absence will be felt acutely.

For the larger Hampton Roads community, Savage and Brock contributed so much — often quietly, always selflessly — that one need not know the men personally to understand the region is better for the fact they lived here and that we are poorer that they are gone.
Useful, honorable, compassionate. To matter, to make a difference.
These are the hallmarks of lives well lived, qualities that Brock and Savage had in abundance.

rows.title: Third time, more harm as Oscar Smith falls to Westfield again in state final
rows.prologue: Noah Kim threw three touchdown passes – including the game-winning, 88-yarder to Gavin Kiley in the third quarter – in a 28-21 victory in the Class 6 football championship game Sunday at Hampton University.
content: HAMPTON
The past two seasons, Oscar Smith and Westfield have played two memorable overtime state championship games only to have the Tigers come up on the losing end .
This season was supposed to be different.
“Third time is a charm,” is what several players said leading into the Class 6 state title game Sunday at Hampton University.

But for the third time, Westfield ended Oscar Smith’s bid for a state title as the Bulldogs beat the Tigers 28-21 to win their third consecutive state title. No team in the Virginia High School League’s largest-enrollment classification – Group AAA Division 6 or Group 6A – had won three consecutive state championships since the 1950s. Phoebus (2008-10) and Hampton (1995-98) won three and four straight, respectively, in Group AAA Division 5.
“It hurts so bad, I can’t even explain it,” said Oscar Smith defensive lineman Kyle Thomas, who finished with eight tackles. “We practiced too hard to get here and lose.”
The Tigers had their chances late. Trailing 28-21 in the fourth quarter, the Tigers had two opportunities to try to send the game into overtime.

The first came with 3:57 left when defensive back Cam’Ron Kelly intercepted Westfield quarterback Noah Kim. He returned the ball to the Westfield 23. But three plays later, Oscar Smith quarterback Dominique Brooks was intercepted by Taylor Morin at the Westfield 1 and he returned it 19 yards with 3:10 left in the game.
The Tigers got another opportunity with 27 seconds left when Keshon Artis forced a fumble on Kim, giving Oscar Smith the ball on its own 49.
Brooks completed a 15-yard pass to BriQuan Harrell to move the ball to the Westfield 36. That was followed by two incompletions.
Then with 6 seconds left, Brooks threw a desperation pass to the end zone that was picked off by Saadiq Hinton at the 1.
“I really thought we were going to go into overtime,” said Westfield coach Kyle Simmons. “I started thinking, ‘I can’t believe this is happening again.’ ”
Oscar Smith also thought they had a chance.

“We were in position to at least tie the game,” said Oscar Smith coach Scott Johnson. “We could have gone for two, maybe, because we had worked on two-point plays. But again it gave us an opportunity to put points on the board. We just didn’t take advantage of it.”
Oscar Smith (12-3) led early when Kelly scored on a 71-yard touchdown run to help give the Tigers the 7-0 lead.
Westfield answered when Morin caught a 46-yard touchdown pass from Kim to tie the game at 7.

Westfield got a break in the second quarter when Kelly fumbled. It was recovered by Elijah Alkins at the Oscar Smith 22. Six plays later, Kim threw a 17-yard touchdown pass to Joe Clancy to help give the Bulldogs a 14-7 lead.
Westfield (15-0) made it 20-7 in the third quarter on running back Eugene Asante’s 44-yard touchdown run. But the Bulldogs missed the extra point.
Brooks helped cut the deficit to 20-14 on a 52-yard touchdown pass to Kelly. Brooks later scored on a 1-yard touchdown run to give the Tigers a 21-20 lead.
But Westfield answered when Kim threw an 88-yard touchdown pass to Gavin Kiley to make it 26-21 and the Bulldogs converted the two-point conversion.
Kelly really thought the Tigers had a chance late.
“I was thinking we were going to go into overtime,” he said. “But they played a great game and we played a great game. They just capitalized on our mistakes.”
Key stats: OS-Khalid Wilson 22-101 rushing; Kelly 9-106, TD rushing; Brooks 5-13-3, 89 yards, TD passing. W-Asante 19-109, TD rushing; Kim 8-21-0, 205 yards, 3 TDs passing; Morin 5-82, TD receiving.

rows.title: Despite state championship game loss, Oscar Smith's football dynasty continues
rows.prologue: Columnist Harry Minium said it will take time for Oscar Smith's football players to appreciate the enormity of what they achieved.
content: HAMPTON

It was impossible Sunday night for Oscar Smith’s football players to grasp the enormity of what they have accomplished. They couldn’t see beyond the fact that they lost a state championship for the third year in a row to the same team, and I can’t blame them.
Two years ago, Westfield High edged the Tigers in three overtimes in the title game.
Last season, it took two overtimes for the team from Fairfax County to prevail.
No overtime was needed Sunday night, but again, it came down to the last play, as Westfield’s Saadiq Hinton intercepted a pass in the end zone to nail down a 28-21 victory at Hampton University.
It’s difficult to have a sense of perspective under those circumstances.
But Westfield coach Kyle Simmons acknowledged the obvious when he said it could have been Oscar Smith hoisting the state championship trophy each of the past three years.
“Oscar Smith could have won tonight,” he said. “They could have won the last two years. That’s how close these teams are.”
It speaks well for Oscar Smith coach Scott Johnson and for the late Bill Dee that the Tigers (12-3) fought their way back to the championship game.

Johnson is the third coach in three years to coach Oscar Smith, and although he noted that the coaching staff has remained largely intact, having a new guy in charge three years in a row can cause a program to lose momentum.
Richard Morgan resigned after the 2015 season to head to suburban Georgia for a new challenge. He was replaced by Dee, who guided the Tigers back to the 2016 title game .
Dee resigned during the offseason for health reasons and succumbed to cancer. Johnson, a long-time Oscar Smith assistant , replaced him.
The Tigers didn’t miss a beat. They were the only Hampton Roads team playing for a state title Sunday, and until someone knocks them off, they remain kings of the hill in the 757.
“There are a awful lot of Division 6 teams that would like to have been here three times,” Johnson said. “This is not easy. It’s a grind and these kids had to battle.
“This speaks so well for our program.”
Many of you may not remember, but for most of its 64 football seasons, Oscar Smith was largely an also- ran.

Morgan came to Chesapeake in 2002 and vowed to build Oscar Smith into a state power. Most were skeptical. Oscar Smith had just two winning records in the past 17 years, and hadn’t won an outright Southeastern District title in four decades.
Morgan said he knew that Oscar Smith “was a sleeping giant.”
“The program was waiting to be revitalized and re-invigorated,” Morgan said. “I saw the stadium, I saw the kids, our facilities. There’s no reason why we couldn’t do it.
“Ninety percent of the people thought I was crazy. People thought I was nuts.”

But there were good athletes and a diverse student body . Oscar Smith long ago moved to a suburban location, away from urban South Norfolk. But those blue-collar, South Norfolk kids still attend school.
Morgan was an emotional hard-charging coach who demanded much of his players, including academic rigor.
He created a “family” atmosphere where players and coaches saw each other frequently off the field, and cared for each other in the off season.
It took him but one season to turn the program around: Oscar Smith was 7-3 in 2002. In 2003, the Tigers won their first Southeastern District title. They’ve won or shared it ever since.
Oscar Smith won its first state title in 2008 and another in 2011.
The Tigers were one play from three more the past three seasons.
King’s Fork coach Scottie Littles played at Landstown, when the Eagles often met the Tigers in the playoffs. He watched Morgan build Oscar Smith into a powerhouse.
“Richard Morgan built a culture of success there,” Littles said. “You coach harder, you play harder, you do everything a little bit better when you have to live up to that standard.”
Morgan said “I’m proud of what we did there, and I’m proud of the kids and coaches for maintaining it.”
Sunday’s game was uncharacteristic for Oscar Smith, which is generally a disciplined team that doesn’t beat itself.

That wasn’t the case at Armstrong Stadium, as Oscar Smith had a season-high five turnovers and the Bulldogs just two. Oscar Smith had ten penalties, including several that helped lead to two Westfield touchdowns.
Cam’Ron Kelly, the four-star junior, was magnificent, and you can see why Alabama, Ohio State and Virginia Tech are beating down his door with scholarship offers.
Playing offense and defense, he ran 71 yards for a touchdown, caught a 52-yard TD pass and intercepted and returned the ball 38 yards to the Westfield 23 with just 3:57 left.
But not even Kelly’s heroics were enough to overcome to many mistakes.
Kelly paid homage to both Dee and Johnson at game’s end.
“They always preached to us that we’re a family,” he said. “That didn’t change. We know our brothers have our back. We never gave up on each other.
“Everybody here has heart.”
And a lot to be proud of.

rows.title: Tech linebacker, U.Va duo earn AP All-America honors
rows.prologue: Tremaine Edmunds becomes the Hokies' first All-American since 2014, while Micah Kiser and Bayside High grad Quin Blanding were honored for the second straight year.
content: Virginia Tech linebacker Tremaine Edmunds has always preferred to pay homage to elders when discussing what he’s learned to make himself a better player. After earning All-America honors Monday along with Virginia linebacker Micah Kiser and safety Quin Blanding, Edmunds can no longer escape the spotlight.

All three were chosen third-team All-Americans by the Associated Press. Kiser and Blanding, a 6-foot-2, 210-pound graduate of Bayside High in Virginia Beach, also earned second-team spots Monday from the Football Writers Association of America.

The AP and the FWAA are two of the five organizations, along with the American Football Coaches Association, the Walter Camp Foundation and The Sporting News, cited by the NCAA when determining consensus and unanimous All-Americans. Kiser and Blanding, both seniors, were chosen second-team All-America last Thursday by the Walter Camp Foundation.

Edmunds becomes No. 22 Tech’s first All-American since 2014, when cornerback Kendall Fuller was chosen second-team Walter Camp and third-team AP. Edmunds, a 6-5, 250-pound junior from Danville, is the first Tech linebacker to earn All-America honors since 2009, when Cody Grimm was picked third-team AP.

“I would say just understanding the game a little bit more,” said Edmunds in early December about how he’s improved in a season in which he was named a finalist for the Butkus Award, which is given to the nation’s top linebacker. “Having a year of experience last year learning from some of those older guys, I’d definitely say that helped me out a lot this year. Just playing faster all around, that helped me out a whole lot.”

Edmunds leads Tech, which plays Dec. 28 in Orlando, Fla., against No. 19 Oklahoma State (9-3, 6-3 Big 12) in the Camping World Bowl, in tackles (102), tackles for loss (14), sacks (5.5) and forced fumbles (three). In Tech’s 10-0 win Nov. 24 at Virginia, he paced  the Hokies with nine tackles, including three for losses and two sacks.
Kiser, a 6-2, 240-pound Baltimore native, and Blanding have earned All-America honors in back-to-back seasons. Kiser was second-team FWAA last season, while Blanding was second-team Sporting News.

There’s also a good chance Kiser and Blanding could finish first and second, respectively, in the ACC in tackles for a second straight season. Kiser leads the conference with 134 tackles, which is also fifth in the nation, and Blanding is second in the ACC with 121 tackles, which is 13th in the nation and first among defensive backs.

Kiser has loaded up on state and national awards this postseason. Last week, he was awarded the William V. Campbell Trophy by the National Football Foundation as the nation’s best football scholar-athlete, and he was given the Dudley Award as the top Division I player in the state of Virginia.

Blanding owns the top spot in the record book at U.Va. (6-6, 3-5 ACC), which plays Dec. 28 in Annapolis, Md., against Navy (6-6, 4-4 American Athletic Conference) in the Military Bowl, in career tackles with 479. If he finishes second in tackles in the ACC this season, it’ll be the fourth straight season he’s done so. He also leads U.Va. this season with four interceptions, which is third in the ACC.

rows.title: Charlottesville denies permit for white supremacist rally anniversary event
rows.byline:
By Joe Heim
The Washington Post
content: Charlottesville, Virginia, officials Monday denied a request to hold a rally in August marking the first anniversary of a protest by white supremacists that turned violent, saying it would endanger public safety.

In a three-paragraph decision signed by City Manager Maurice Jones, the city said the request for a permit "cannot be accommodated with the area applied for, or within a reasonable allocation of city funds and/or police resources."

Jason Kessler filed the request for a permit last month to hold a "rally against government civil rights abuse and failure to follow security plans for political dissidents," and to memorialize "the sacrifices made by political dissidents in Lee Park August 12, 2017." Kessler was the primary organizer of the Aug. 12 Unite the Right rally that drew neo-Nazis and white nationalists to Charlottesville, leading to bloody clashes in the streets with counterprotesters.

On Monday, the city said Kessler's application for a rally next year "likely underestimates the number of participants" and declared that the city does not have the police resources to identify opposing groups and keep them separated.

"The applicant requests that police keep 'opposing sides' separate and that police 'leave' a 'clear path into event without threat of violence,' but city does not have the ability to determine or sort individuals according to what 'side' they are on, and no reasonable allocation of city funds or resources can guarantee that event participants will be free of any 'threat of violence,' " the city stated.

Charlottesville officials also said Kessler had included no information on how he would be responsible for the behavior of participants or how he could be held accountable for their adherence to city regulations.
Kessler blasted the city's ruling, threatened legal action and vowed he would not be deterred.

"The decision is bogus and should be reversed in court," he wrote in an email. "We're going to be suing Charlottesville for this and many other civil rights violations starting early next year. And the rally is still happening."

Citing similar public safety constraints and insufficient police and financial resources, the city denied four other permit requests from opponents and supporters of Kessler to hold events in public parks on the anniversary weekend.

The violence that marked the rally worsened when James Alex Fields Jr., a 20-year-old Nazi sympathizer from Ohio, allegedly drove his Dodge Challenger into a crowd of counterprotesters, killing Heather Heyer, 32, and injuring 19 others. Two Virginia state troopers who had been monitoring the events from the airdied later that day when their helicopter crashed.

In a post on his blog last month announcing the permit request, Kessler blamed police for not breaking up fights between rallygoers and counterprotesters, and for not providing adequate protection to allow the rally to proceed.
Charlottesville's handling of the Unite the Right rally, particularly its police response, was uniformly criticized in a 207-page independent review released Dec. 1.

rows.title: Virginia student says he was thrown out of class for not saying the pledge
rows.prologue: A teacher in Fairfax County who allegedly disciplined a high school student for refusing to stand for the Pledge of Allegiance breached system rules and will not be returning to the classroom.
rows.byline:
By Debbie Truong
The Washington Post
content: A teacher in Fairfax County who allegedly disciplined a high school student for refusing to stand for the Pledge of Allegiance breached system rules and will not be returning to the classroom, school district administrators decided following an investigation.
The episode was reported to officials at Centreville High School by the student, who said the teacher yelled for him to stand and then yanked him from his seat when he wouldn't.

"The incident at Centreville High School is unacceptable behavior by a classroom instructor and directly violates an existing and long-standing [Fairfax County Public Schools] policy," Fairfax Superintendent Scott Brabrand said in an emailed statement.

Brabrand's statement did not identify the student or teacher, but the student said in an interview that the teacher is Richard Ferrick. An attorney for Ferrick, James K. Freeman, said in an email that the "allegations are without merit," but declined further comment.
The student, Eric Trammel, recalled that the November morning began like so many before, with a familiar morning ritual at Centreville.
Students around Trammel rose for the Pledge of Allegiance. But the sophomore did as he has for more than a year: He remained seated.
This time, Ferrick ordered the 15-year-old to rise, Trammel recalled. When he refused, Ferrick pulled Trammel by the arm and sent him outside, the teenager said.
"He was really angry when he grabbed my arm," Trammel said. "I just never really saw it coming."

Employees in the Fairfax County Public Schools are forbidden from disciplining students who do not participate in the pledge, according to district policy. Students who abstain are expected to sit or stand quietly, the policy states.
The school district declined to say if the teacher was fired because it does not publicly discuss personnel matters.

Trammel hasn't stood for the morning recitation since encountering the Black Lives Matter movement on Twitter during the eighth grade. He views the quiet demonstration as his way of drawing attention to unequal racial treatment and other forms of inequality, he said.

"The country is in a very divided place right now and there's a lot of injustices around the U.S. I feel like me sitting can spread awareness to that," Trammel said. "I don't believe in forcing other people to sit. . . . That's just a personal decision."
Similar actions have captured national attention.

In 2016, Colin Kaepernick became one of the country'smost polarizing sports figures when, as a former quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, he took a knee during the national anthem in protest of police violence against black people.

Kaepernick gained renewed attention earlier this year after President Donald Trump, during a campaign rally in Alabama for Republican Sen. Luther Strange, went off topic and said, "Wouldn't you love to see one of these NFL owners, when somebody disrespects our flag, to say, 'Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, out. He's fired. He's fired!' "

Unlike the animated national discourse ignited by Trump's remarks and subsequent tweets, Trammel's display drew little fuss until Nov. 14, he said. It was his second day in driver's education class, he said, when Ferrick spotted him sitting for the Pledge of Allegiance during first period.

After being thrown out of class, Trammel said he spent 20 minutes outside in the cold before knocking and asking Ferrick if he could return. The teacher allegedly refused unless Trammel agreed to stand for the pledge.
"This isn't the NFL," Trammel recalled the teacher saying.
"This has nothing to do with the NFL," Trammel said he responded, adding that he explained to Ferrick that he had the right to sit through the pledge.
When the teacher refused to let Trammel return, the teen said he went to school administrators, who walked with him back to class.
The administrators, whom Trammel declined to name, spoke with Ferrick as Trammel returned to class and quietly took notes. The teacher, Trammel said, pulled him aside after class.
"He told me that our relationship had drastically changed, that what he thought of me was different," Trammel said. "He also moved me to the back of the classroom."
Trammel detailed the encounter in a text message to his mother, Angela Trammel, soon after.
"I was respectful and said it is a right I have to sit in class and he basically tried to say his class rules override that," Angela Trammel said her son wrote.
The mother said she was unaware her son felt so fiercely about the Pledge of Allegiance.

"I'm pretty proud of his courage. I'm more proud that he behaved well throughout his courage," she said. "As a mother, I want Eric to know he's going to be protected and he doesn't have to make any concessions when he's been mistreated, ever."
The family is looking into legal options. Victor M. Glasberg, one of the attorneys representing the family, described Trammel's refusal to back down as admirable.
"In this political climate, any time anybody stands up to say no is important," Glasberg said. "Particularly when it's done politely, with appropriate deference and respect."
Trammel's father, Ernest Trammel, stood by his son.

"He has the right to voice his opinion and do his thing, as long as he's peacefully doing it," Ernest Trammel said. "When we, as Americans, stop standing up for what we believe is right, we basically accept the injustice."
Trammel said he hasn't since encountered other issues in his driver's education class, where he has an A, he said.

rows.title: Virginia has a teacher shortage. Are fast-tracked degrees a solution?
rows.prologue: As Virginia schools struggle with a dearth of teachers, Gov. Terry McAuliffe wants colleges and universities to be able to fast-track the schooling of aspiring educators.
content: As Virginia schools struggle with a dearth of teachers, Gov. Terry McAuliffe wants colleges and universities to be able to fast-track the training of aspiring educators.

McAuliffe signed an executive order Monday directing the state Board of Education to adopt emergency rules that would allow colleges and universities to offer a four-year undergraduate degree in teaching, rather than a five-year master’s program.

“Given the cost of higher education and the severe need for additional teachers, I believe changing this requirement will encourage more Virginians to pursue careers in education and will help supply more future teachers to meet the growing needs of our public school system,” McAuliffe said in the directive.
He ordered the board to adopt the rules by March 1, 2018.
McAuliffe also announced five budget actions to address teacher shortages. Those include providing:

• $1.1 million to automate the state’s teacher licensure process
  • $1 million to recruit and retain principals in the state’s “most challenged school divisions”
  • $225,000 more to the Tuition Assistance Grant program to persuade students attending private colleges and universities in Virginia to pursue teaching. Each student who pursues an education degree would receive an extra $500.
  • $100,000 to help provisionally licensed minority students pay for tests and test-preparation programs
  • Changes to the Virginia Teaching Scholarship Loan Program that would make students eligible for up to $20,000 if they teach for two years in a top-five critical shortage area in a high-poverty school division.

Special education, elementary education and middle education are the top three critical shortage teaching endorsements in Virginia this school year, according to the state Education Department. The state’s public schools entered this year with about 1,000 vacant teaching positions, according to the Virginia Education Association.

rows.title: Prominent attorney, philanthropist Toy Savage Jr. dies at the age of 96
rows.prologue: A former state delegate and longtime partner of law firm Willcox Savage, he helped form Eastern Virginia Medical School and the region's trash authority.
rows.tagline:
Pilot researcher Jakon Hays contributed to this report.

scott.daugherty@pilotonline.com
content: NORFOLK
Toy Savage Jr. was a man of many hats.

Yes, he was a former member of the Virginia House of Delegates and spent almost 70 years as a partner at Willcox Savage, the law firm that bears his family’s name. But friends and family said Savage, who died Thursday at 96, also was active with the United Way of South Hampton Roads and the Chrysler Museum of Art. And he helped form Eastern Virginia Medical School and the authority that oversees the region’s trash collection and disposal, among other things.
“It was who dad was,” Toy Savage III said of his father’s varied interests.
He and his sister, Tracy Savage, said their father had no particular passion for medicine or the arts. Rather, they said, he wanted to do whatever he could to make life better for everyone.

“For him it was always a question of, what were the most pressing problems of the day facing the community,” said longtime friend Rusty Friddell, the executive vice president and general counsel of Landmark Media Enterprises LLC, which owns The Virginian-Pilot. “That was where you would find him.”

Friends and family described the longtime philanthropist as intelligent, self-disciplined and an avid lover of the law – particularly corporate, tax and estate-planning issues. The firm represents The Virginian-Pilot in some legal matters.

Savage’s children said he worked until the day he died – not because he had to, but because he enjoyed what he was doing. His son said a lot of that dedication came from the relationships he developed over the years while leading the firm.
“All of his friends were clients and all of his clients were friends,” Friddell added.
Toy Savage III recalled how his father used to tell his children they should find jobs they love because then it would never seem like work.
“And then he would say he had actually had to work very few days,” the son said.

Toy Savage Sr. founded the law firm later led by his son, according to Robert Dewey, its current managing partner. He said a Savage has been practicing at the firm for more than 115 years, except for a short break during World War II while Toy Savage Jr. was serving in the Navy.
In 1958, Toy Savage Jr. and his friend Thomas Willcox Jr. merged their firms to create Willcox Savage.

Savage was recognized several times for his work in the community. In 1980, he was named Norfolk’s First Citizen. And in 2012, he received the Hampton Roads Community Foundation’s Barron Black Community Builder Award.
Tracy Savage said her father always was looking toward the future and thinking long term.

“He would never use the word strategic, but that was exactly what he was. He was a very strategic person that way,” she said, noting his efforts to help found EVMS. She said her father supported the school not for its short-term benefits, but because he believed it would eventually lead more doctors to settle in the area.

rows.title: Judge denies Pentagon bid to delay Jan. 1 deadline to accept transgender recruits
rows.prologue: The ruling from  U.S. District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly follows her earlier opinion blocking the president's ban on military recruitment of transgender men and women.
rows.byline:
By Ann E. Marimow and Spencer S. Hsu
The Washington Post
content: WASHINGTON

A federal judge on Monday denied the Trump administration's request to delay an order requiring the military to begin accepting transgender recruits starting Jan. 1 saying the argument for more time seemed based on "vague claims."
"The Court is not persuaded that Defendants will be irreparably injured by" meeting the New Year's Day deadline, U.S. District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly wrote.

The ruling from Kollar-Kotelly of the District of Columbia follows her earlier opinion blocking the president's ban on military recruitment of transgender men and women that possibly would have forced the dismissal of current service members starting in March.

"With only a brief hiatus, Defendants have had the opportunity to prepare for the accession of transgender individuals into the military for nearly one and a half years," when the policy was initially issued in June 2016, she wrote. "Especially in light of the record evidence showing, with specifics, that considerable work has already been done, the Court is not convinced by the vague claims in [the government's] declaration that a stay is needed.

A second federal judge in Baltimore also issued a preliminary injunction in November that goes further in preventing the administration from denying funding for sex-reassignment surgeries after the order takes effect.

Justice Department spokeswoman Lauren Ehrsam said, "We disagree with the Courts ruling and are currently evaluating the next steps. Plaintiffs' lawsuit challenging military service requirements is premature for many reasons, including that the Defense Department is actively reviewing such service requirements, as the President ordered, and because none of the Plaintiffs have established that they will be impacted by current policies on military service."

In July, President Donald Trump surprised military leaders and members of Congress when he announced the proposal in a series of tweets. Trump's order reversed an Obama-era policy allowing transgender men and women to serve openly and to receive funding for sex-reassignment surgery.

In October, Kollar-Kotelly found challengers likely to prevail in asserting that the president's order violates equal-protection guarantees in the Constitution. The administration has appealed the ruling, and in the meantime asked the judge to temporarily postpone the recruitment requirement until the case is resolved.
Forcing the military to accept transgender applicants and implement such a significant change in policy may "negatively impact military readiness," government lawyers said in asking for the delay.

Attorneys for the plaintiffs said in court filings that the military had already been preparing to accept transgender recruits. Before the change in administration, the Defense Department was gearing up to accept transgender applicants starting in July 2017 and had started training and other preparations.

"The government cannot credibly claim that it will be irreparably harmed by implementing a policy that it was on track to implement almost six months ago," according to the filing from the plaintiffs.

rows.title: Renelle Roberts, voice-over actress | First person
rows.prologue: A former reporter, Roberts now uses her voice to inspire and sell, performing voice-over work such as commercials and e-learning videos for businesses.
content: RENELLE ROBERTS IS USED TO BEING THE ONE ASKING the questions and learning about others.
So, it was a bit odd for the 35 year old former reporter turned full time professional voice-over actress and narrator to be on the opposite side sharing her story.
The sole proprietor of her business, Roberts is Los Angeles trained and has done everything from national commercials to audio books to training and e-learning videos for local businesses.
A Connecticut native, Roberts represented her state in 2000 in the Miss America pageant.

She received her bachelor’s degree in media studies from Southern Connecticut State University in 2002 and her master’s in broadcast journalism from Regent University in 2004. For almost a decade, Roberts worked as a television features producer and reporter for CBN through its affiliate Freeform, formerly the ABC Family channel.
Her husband, Casey, is a principal at Smithfield High School. Roberts decided she would stay home to raise their daughter, Daphney, who is 5.
From her in-home studio in Chesapeake, Roberts can work with people all over the world.
“I have the capability to communicate with them and record for them and get projects back to them very quickly. So it’s been a blessing. It’s been a dream come true really,” Roberts said.
CHILDHOOD DREAMS COME TRUE

“I wanted to be an entertainment reporter actually when I was a little girl. I always wanted to be in television. We didn’t have cable growing up, we only had channel 8 (ABC) at our house. So my celebrities were my local news reporters and national news reporters. That’s just all I saw because that’s all we had. So, I would write fan letters to them and that’s what I wanted to be.

“I also had another dream of being Miss America, which I think a lot of little girls back then dreamt of. I did actually get to partially accomplish that. I was a junior in college at 18 when I won the Miss Connecticut title and got to compete in Miss America … it was so much fun and that also opened me up to a wider spectrum of journalism because when you’re Miss Connecticut for a year, you’re doing lots of appearances and you’re with reporters a lot. That kind of just showed me even more of what print and broadcast journalism are about and that helped fuel my love for reporting.”
COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT

“I am a member of the (Hampton Roads) Chamber of Commerce. I love going to chamber events. I’m also a member of the Virginia Production Alliance. There are wonderful gatherings where we get to meet people in the industry. And so those are wonderful groups that I highly endorse. The chamber has been wonderful for learning about the local businesses and the Virginia Production Alliance is great because it gets me to meet people not just in Hampton roads, but people all over Virginia involved in film and television production. And so that’s been really really helpful.”
SPARE TIME

“We love to go for walks. My daughter is really into violin, so as a family we like to go to the Virginia Symphony orchestra performances, especially their kids’ performances. We love musical theater, so we like supporting the Hurrah Players, anything that comes to the Chrysler. … Every summer, we do take a family vacation to Martha’s Vineyard with our extended family. That’s one of the highlights of our year…relaxing, playing board games and that kind of thing. Just being out in nature, being together as a family and that brings us a lot of joy.”
HUMANITARIAN WORK

“My husband and I are very passionate about humanitarian work. We’ve gone together to Southern India…we help out at a children’s home and help widows. We’re hoping to take our daughter when she’s a bit older. ... We’ve been involved for the last 10 years in helping out there and supplying school uniforms for the children and shoes for them and supporting a local school there. It’s important to live our own lives, but we also need to remember that there are people who are less fortunate in our country and other countries. And to keep that as something primary in our radar so we don’t just get consumed with ourselves.”
10 YEARS FROM NOW

“I really see myself just continuing down this path. There’s a lot going on in society now — the theme of living your best life — and I honestly feel like I’ve reached that. I know life isn’t perfect, we have our problems like everybody else, but for me, being a wife, being a mom, and being a voice actress is my definition of success. And so if I could be doing the same things, still doing voice overs, still spending time with my family in 10 years, then I would be as happy as a queen.”

rows.title: JMU's chasing another FCS title ... with a little help from some ex-FBS guys
rows.prologue: James Madison has found great success as a landing spot for players at major-college programs who want more playing time or a new start.
content: HARRISONBURG
Ron’Dell Carter said he was determined to give the new coaching staff at Rutgers a chance.

Recruited by a former regime, Carter played in five games for Rutgers in 2016 for first-year head coach Chris Ash and was confident he would have seen significant action this season for the Scarlet Knights.

But when he decided to transfer – to assure that he would see the field more often – he had a key ally down a level at James Madison : his younger brother, Robert Carter Jr. Robert was a linebacker for the Dukes who played in 15 games during JMU’s 2016 national championship season.

Big brother realizes there is less media attention and not as much free gear at the Football Championship Subdivision level when compared with Rutgers and other Power 5 schools. But he’s OK with that.

“All of that stuff gets old if you are not happy,” said Ron’Dell, a Baltimore native who’s now a redshirt sophomore defensive lineman for unbeaten and top-ranked JMU. “It wasn’t an easy process. I think the goals are the same (down a level): You want to win. My biggest thing was to win.”
Carter and his teammates are certainly doing a lot of that. JMU takes a 13-0 mark and a 25-game win streak into the FCS semifinals Saturday.

The Dukes will host South Dakota State (11-2) at 4:30 p.m. . The winner advances to take on North Dakota State or Sam Houston State in the national title game next month in Frisco, Texas. The other semifinal is Friday night.
The Dukes advanced with a thrilling 31-28 win at home Friday night, with Ethan Ratke’s last-second field goal making the difference before an ESPN2 national television audience .
“That was positively the best win I have ever had in my life,” said Ron’Dell Carter, who had three tackles. “Just to be part of that was very special.”

JMU, like many top FCS programs, benefits greatly from the transfer of players from Football Bowl Subdivision schools. This season, the roster includes three players from the University of Virginia: receiver David Eldridge, defensive lineman Darrious Carter and linebacker Landan Word. Sophomore cornerback Sidney Wellons, an Indian River High grad, transferred from Morehead State.
JMU head coach Mike Houston, owner of a gaudy 27-1 record in two years with the Dukes, said a program has to be careful when considering high-level transfers.

“We are at a place that attracts a lot of attention for guys that are looking to transfer,” Houston said Monday. “I get multiple requests a week. We have (good) character people in our program. I want to make sure I protect that. We do a good bit of research.

“There is a reason they are leaving (another school). They could just be unhappy. All of the players that we have brought in have handled themselves well. No huge egos; normally, guys put their head down and work.”

Marcus Marshall, in his first season at JMU, spent two seasons as a top running back at Georgia Tech . That was a homecoming of sorts for the Raleigh, N.C., native, since both parents attended JMU and his father, Warren, was a Hall of Fame running back for the Dukes and played briefly with the Denver Broncos.

“The only (other) place I considered in the end was Iowa. That was it,” said Marshall, who rushed for 1,278 and averaged about seven yards a carry in two seasons with the Yellow Jackets. “My parents were here, my uncle went here. It felt like home. When I got here, everyone treated me like I had been here for years.”

The junior running back ran for 128 yards on 14 carries and scored two touchdowns in the quarterfinal victory. A third TD run was called back because of a penalty. Marshall ran 43 yards on one play in the first quarter after the Dukes had gained just 49 yards on the ground in a playoff victory the previous weekend against Stony Brook .
“That definitely set the tone. He had an amazing game,” Ron’Dell Carter said of Marshall.
Marshall has 617 yards and eight TDs this season, including a season-high 135 yards against Maine. He said moving down a level doesn’t affect his goals.
“Since I was 6 years old, I wanted to go to college and play in the NFL,” he said. “If you came down a level and tried to alter that, you would be selling yourself short.”
The Dukes certainly aren’t doing that. Not with defense of their national title on the line.
“Everyone is going to give their best to knock us off,” Ron’Dell Carter said. “It is very, very hard to be No. 1.”
He noted that validation of his transfer and those of others from Power 5 schools can be seen in the Dukes’ locker room.
“You will see how happy I am,” he said

rows.title: Chesapeake man gets 4 years for DUI crash on I-264 that killed a 22-year-old Norfolk woman
rows.prologue: Christopher Hudson Kita had been out on bond on a drunken driving charge for less than a month last March when he crashed his truck into the back of a stopped car on Interstate 264 and killed a Norfolk woman.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH
Christopher Hudson Kita had been out on bond on a drunken driving charge for less than a month when he crashed his truck into the back of a stopped car on Interstate 264, killing a Norfolk woman.

On Monday, Circuit Judge Glenn Croshaw sentenced the Chesapeake man to four years and one month in prison. The judge also suspended his license indefinitely, fined him $500, and ordered that he participate in an alcohol rehabilitation program.
Kita pleaded no contest in August to DUI involuntary manslaughter and guilty to driving under the influence for the March 5 crash that killed 22-year-old Teja Freeman of Norfolk.

Deputy Commonwealth’s Attorney David Laird said it was “shocking to the conscience” that Kita, 29, would have been out drinking and driving recklessly on the interstate so soon after having been charged with drunken driving.
Kita’s earlier DUI charge came on Feb. 9 in Chesapeake. He pleaded guilty in June to the lesser charge of reckless driving and was sentenced to 90 days in jail.

After the fatal crash in Virginia Beach, Kita’s blood alcohol content tested at 0.14 percent , nearly twice the legal limit for driving. A black box from his truck estimated his speed was 78 mph when he crashed around 3:30 a.m. on I-264 west near Witchduck Road.
A witness told prosecutors that Kita had been tailgating him just before the wreck. He said Kita drove around him, revving his engine and speeding up . The collision happened moments later.
Freeman was in a Mazda sedan that was stopped in the highway’s left lane with one blinker on.

She was pronounced dead at the scene. It was unknown why her vehicle was stopped, Laird said. A medical examiner’s report showed that Freeman also was intoxicated. Her blood alcohol content tested at 0.19 percent.
Freeman, a certified dental assistant, was working as a retail store manager, her mother, Mia Freeman, told the court.
The younger Freeman was planning to enroll at Norfolk State University .
“She had so many goals and she will not get the chance to complete any of those,” her mom said.
Before he was sentenced, Kita said, “This accident has changed me forever.
“I will dedicate the rest of my life to honoring her memory.”

rows.title: ODU could have 4 players in NFL games this weekend
rows.prologue: Columnist Harry Minium says that after nine football seasons, ODU is finally establishing a footprint in the NFL.
content: After nine football seasons, Old Dominion is finally establishing a footprint in the NFL.

Before this year, long snapper Rick Lovato was the only ODU alumnus to have played in an NFL game. But that number could grow to four this weekend, as former Monarch quarterback Taylor Heinicke appears likely to be activated by the Houston Texans.

Houston’s starter, Tom Savage, suffered a concussion Sunday and almost surely won’t play for the Texans at Jacksonville next Sunday. That means Heinicke, now on the practice squad, would dress and serve as the backup.

Defensive tackle Rashaad Coward, a key player on ODU’s Bahamas Bowl-winning team last season, and receiver Larry Pinkard, who last played at ODU four years ago, were recently promoted from practice squads and saw action Sunday.

Coward played briefly in Chicago’s 33-7 victory over Cincinnati. He did not have a tackle but had one quarterback hit and “played well,” ODU coach Bobby Wilder said in between recruiting stops on Monday.

Pinkard has played four games for Jacksonville and caught his first career pass (a 5-yarder) in Sunday’s 30-24 victory over Seattle. “Larry is playing for a team fighting to win a division title,” Wilder said. “Yesterday was a great day for our program.”

Lovato played in Green Bay, Washington and Philly over the past two seasons before winning the job with the Eagles in preseason camp. He has played in 13 games with Philadelphia, which is 11-2 and tied with Pittsburgh for the NFL’s best record.

Pinkard is perhaps the most surprising success story. He was dismissed from ODU shortly before practice began in 2014, his senior year, for an unspecified violation of team rules. He has been in out and out of pro training camps ever since.
He worked out with Heinicke before ODU’s Pro Day in 2015, and the two remain close. Sunday, they will be on the same field again in Jacksonville.
Hampton talked with Atlantic 10 Hampton University aimed a lot higher than the Big South Conference when seeking to join a new league.

Hampton President William Harvey negotiated for months with the Atlantic 10, and those discussions ended only days before the Pirates announced they would join the Big South, sources at two schools said.

Good for Harvey for shooting for the stars. The A-10 makes a lot more sense for Hampton than the Big South. The conference annually sends several teams to the men’s basketball tournament, and has in-state rivals Virginia Commonwealth, Richmond and George Mason.

Moving to the A-10 would have left HU’s football program without a home, but presumably, the Pirates could have joined the Big South for football only, or perhaps would have remained in the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference.

HU’s status in the MEAC is still undetermined. When the Pirates announced last month that they were leaving for the Big South, MEAC officials declined comment when asked if Hampton would be allowed to play in its men’s and women’s basketball tournaments.

MEAC presidents were scheduled to meet this week in Atlanta, but that was postponed, league spokeswoman Patricia Easley said. When they finally convene, the issue of whether to keep the basketball tournaments in Norfolk or move elsewhere also is likely to be decided.
Another Kenny Easley at Oscar Smith?

When Kenny Easley was a Parade All-American at Oscar Smith High School four decades ago, he rarely left the field. He played quarterback and safety, returned punts and kickoffs and even punted. He had to because the Tigers were so shorthanded.

Oscar Smith junior Cam’Ron Kelly appears almost as versatile. He played quarterback, tailback, receiver and safety in the Tigers’ 28-21 loss to Westfield in the Class 6 state championship game Sunday .
The four-star recruit had 106 yards rushing, 52 receiving yards, returned an interception 38 yards, completed two passes and scored two touchdowns.

Virginia Tech assistant Zohn Burden attended the game not only to see and be seen by Kelly, but also to watch Hokies commit Keshon Artis, a linebacker who had eight tackles, a forced fumble, one tackle for a loss and a blocked punt.

Charlotte fans need a reality check Charlotte athletic director Judy Rose riled up the masses in the Queen City when she announced recently that Brad Lambert will continue as football coach. Fans have been calling for Rose to be fired, and it reached such a crescendo that Chancellor Philip Dubois came to her defense.

The fans weren't just riled up because of football. Charlotte's once-mighty basketball program has floundered, especially after the 49ers joined Conference USA. Football and basketball attendance have cratered.
But is was the decision to retain Lambert that lit the fuse.

The 49ers are coming off an 1-11 season, so some consternation is understandable. But Charlotte fans need a little reality check. The school took a hugely challenging step when it began football in 2013 with the intent of moving to Conference USA in 2015. Two 5-6 FCS seasons were followed by 2-10 and 4-8 records.
Lambert is a respected coach who competes for recruits in the same state with four ACC schools, Appalachian State and East Carolina. Clemson and the entire SEC are to the South.

Charlotte has virtually no football tradition and is a tough sell to recruits with so many options. And this year’s record was predictable after the 49ers lost 10 starters and many top backups to graduation after last season.
Charlotte should be much better in 2018, when 39 of the top 44 players return, including every starter and backup on defense.
Retaining Lambert was a difficult choice, but the right one.
