rows.title: Atlantic Coast Pipeline gets a big OK from the state -- along with a big "if"
rows.prologue: Virginia's water board narrowly approved a certification for the Dominion Energy-led project, and reserved the right to take it up again after state environmental staffers complete a range of reviews.
content: RICHMOND

Opponents of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline packed a meeting room Tuesday, expecting Virginia’s water board would hand their cause a resounding defeat. Some of the loudest and youngest among them prepared to demonstrate — and perhaps get arrested — before the proceedings were over. Dozens of police cars outside indicated the authorities were expecting trouble too.

Instead, the sometimes-raucous meeting ended with confusion, not uproar, and a partial victory for foes of the natural gas pipeline. Though a few protesters were escorted out after ignoring warnings to quiet down, police said there were no arrests.

The members of the State Water Control Board approved a certification for the controversial project, but the 4-3 vote was only a tentative endorsement. The board delayed its effective date, reserving the option of voting again on the project after the Department of Environmental Quality staff completes reviews of the pipeline partners’ plans to address a range of issues. Among unresolved matters: controls on stormwater runoff and erosion protections for steep mountain slopes.

The outcome left opponents comparing notes and offering somewhat different interpretations. It caught the project’s lead partner, Dominion Energy, off guard. The company is considered Virginia’s most politically powerful, and its project has enjoyed the backing of Gov. Terry McAuliffe, who appointed the members of the water board. In addition, the board last week issued a certification for another highly contested project, the Mountain Valley Pipeline, with few stipulations.

In a statement several hours after the vote, Dominion spokesman Aaron Ruby called the board action a “major step toward final approval” and said the company will work closely with DEQ “to complete all remaining approvals in a timely manner and ensure we meet all conditions of the certification.”

Dominion had once indicated it hoped to begin construction of the Atlantic Coast Pipeline before year’s end, but Bill Hayden, a DEQ spokesman, said he didn’t see how that was possible. Hayden said it wasn’t clear how long the staff reviews the board decided to wait for would take.
The 600-mile pipeline would carry fracked natural gas from the mountains of West Virginia to the lowlands of eastern North Carolina, with a spur into Hampton Roads ending in Chesapeake.

Dominion has made the $5 billion line a centerpiece of its long-term energy strategy, arguing it would help it continue its move away from dirtier-burning coal as a fuel source while meeting a growing demand for electricity. Much of Virginia’s business and labor community, and most members of Hampton Roads’ General Assembly delegation have voiced support, citing Dominion’s claims that it would create 13,000 construction jobs and lower electricity prices.

Critics, including environmentalists and many landowners along the route, have said the construction would irreparably damage streams and rivers. They argue the project would drive up electricity prices and have called on Dominion to invest more in solar, wind and other renewable sources.

More than 20,000 public comments, most in opposition, have been submitted to state environmental regulators on the project. Opponents outnumbered supporters again Monday, when the water board invited public speakers.
Tuesday was devoted to the DEQ staff’s review of the pipeline, and though that work is not finished, the staff recommended the board give its certification.
That troubled some board members, including Roberta Kellam from Northampton County. She said they needed more information before signing off and called for an unequivocal rejection.

Some members who did vote for the provisional certification said they did so despite concerns that a delay on final action might cost the board its right to impose water-quality guidelines. They noted that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which approved the project in October, has a one-year window during which state officials must act or waive their oversight. Hayden said it isn’t clear when that countdown began.

David Sligh, conservation director for the nonprofit group Wild Virginia, praised the board for acknowledging that “the process is flawed and they can’t in good faith make a final decision without all the information.”

rows.title: It was "heartbreaking" for Trump's accusers to see him elected despite sexual misconduct allegations
rows.prologue: Trump has denied all of the allegations against him, which were made public after The Washington Post published an "Access Hollywood" recording of Trump boasting about grabbing women by the genitals in October 2016.
rows.byline:
By Mark Berman
The Washington Post
content: As the country grapples with a national reckoning over sexual misconduct allegations against powerful men from Hollywood to Capitol Hill, three women who accused the most high-profile man in the country again questioned Monday why their claims did nothing to stop him from winning the presidency.

It was "heartbreaking" for women to go public with their claims against President Donald Trump last year, only to see him ascend to the Oval Office, said Samantha Holvey, a former Miss USA contestant who in October 2016 said Trump inappropriately inspected pageant participants.

"I put myself out there for the entire world and nobody cared," Holvey said on NBC's "Megyn Kelly Today" show, appearing for an hour alongside Jessica Leeds, a New York woman who said Trump groped her on a plane, and Rachel Crooks, who said Trump kissed her on the lips after she introduced herself to him at Trump Tower.

Trump has denied all of the allegations against him, which were made public after The Washington Post published an "Access Hollywood" recording of Trump boasting about grabbing women by the genitals in October 2016. The White House's position is that Trump's accusers are lying and that the issue was settled when he was elected president after the stories emerged.

"These false claims, totally disputed in most cases by eyewitness accounts, were addressed at length during last year's campaign, and the American people voiced their judgment by delivering a decisive victory," the White House said in a statement Monday. "The timing and absurdity of these false claims speaks volumes, and the publicity tour that has begun only further confirms the political motives behind them."
Speaking to Megyn Kelly on Monday in their first joint interview, the women recounted their allegations against Trump, describing how they felt threatened and disgusted by their encounters with him.

"I was shocked," Crooks told Kelly after describing Trump kissing her at Trump Tower. "Devastated. It happened so fast ... I wish I would've been courageous enough to say, 'What's going on and you need to stop this.'"

Crooks said she felt at the time that she had no way to respond to the situation out of fear that if she reported it to her bosses - who did business with Trump's organization - she might lose her job. "I wish I had been stronger," she said. Crooks said she came forward after reading an account from another woman accusing Trump of misconduct, saying that this made her feel a sense of relief knowing that "it wasn't just me."

The three women spoke on "Today" before holding a news conference in Manhattan amid a wave of allegations of sexual assault and harassment by men that have swept across the country in recent weeks that has stretched into fields including politics, entertainment, the media, the courts and the finance industry.

Numerous high-profile men have been fired or suspended from their jobs, including Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein and broadcaster Charlie Rose, while others have announced plans to step down, including Sen. Al Franken, D-Minn., and Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., both of whom said last week that they would leave Congress over the mounting allegations.
Holvey suggested it made sense for Trump's accusers to speak to the public again given the way the country's atmosphere - and response to alleged sexual misconduct - has shifted over the last year.
"Let's try round two," she said. "The environment's different, let's try again."

A day before the women spoke, Nikki Haley, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said that women who have accused Trump "should be heard." Haley's comments were a sharp break from the White House's position, and they were particularly notable coming from one of the most high-profile women serving in Trump's administration.

"They should be heard, and they should be dealt with," Haley said when asked on CBS's "Face the Nation" about the allegations other women have made against Trump. "And I think we heard from them before the election. And I think any woman who has felt violated or felt mistreated in any way, they have every right to speak up."

The #MeToo movement has drawn renewed attention to the accusations against Trump, which emerged in the final weeks of the presidential campaign last year. When asked in October whether the White House's position was that all of the women are lying, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, Trump's press secretary, told reporters: "Yeah, we've been clear on that from the beginning, and the president has spoken on it."

For women who accused Trump of sexual misconduct last year, watching other men felled by allegations has left them wondering why their claims did not have the same impact during the presidential campaign.
Trump has denied the allegations against him, vowing to sue his accusers and produce "substantial evidence" he said would disprove their claims. So far, he has not followed through on either promise.

One lawsuit has emerged from the allegations made against Trump: One of his accusers, Summer Zervos, sued him in New York for defamation over Trump's repeated comments that all of the women were liars.

Zervos, a former contestant on "The Apprentice," said Trump kissed and groped her during a 2007 encounter at the Beverly Hills Hotel. In response, Trump said: "False stories. All made up. Lies. Lies. No witnesses. No nothing. All big lies."

Trump's attorneys have decried Zervos's lawsuit, calling it "politically motivated" and based on allegations of something "that never occurred." They have sought to have the suit dismissed, arguing that he was expressing a political opinion and saying a sitting U.S. president cannot be sued in state court.

rows.title: Liberty Tax's own independent accountants, concerned with John Hewitt's control, resign
rows.prologue: KPMG, one of country's four largest accounting firms, told the company that Hewitt's actions "have created an inappropriate tone at the top."
rows.tagline: Kimberly Pierceall, 757-550-1903, kimberly.pierceall@pilotonline.com. Follow on Facebook at fb.me/news.pierceall.
content: John T. Hewitt’s continued control of Liberty Tax’s board, despite his having been fired from his role as CEO in September, has led the company’s independent auditor to resign.
KPMG, one of country’s four largest accounting firms, told Liberty Tax that the actions of the former CEO and current board chairman “have created an inappropriate tone at the top.”

In a one-page filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Liberty Tax said KPMG resigned on Friday, a day after the tax prep company was supposed to report its quarterly earnings, which were postponed indefinitely. Liberty Tax said Monday that it’s working to hire a new independent registered public accounting firm to finish its quarterly earnings.

Liberty Tax fired Hewitt following a report from an outside law firm that investigated allegations of wrongdoing by Hewitt. The report concluded that there was credible evidence that Hewitt played favorites with franchisees and staff he was rumored to be in relationships with, was overheard having sex in his office, and used company resources for his personal benefit including arranging out of town meetings around the New York Yankees’ baseball schedule.

Since his firing, Hewitt has remained chairman of the company’s nine-member board because he owns controlling shares of stock and replaced two of his board appointees. One independent board member resigned and another said he would not seek re-election. The company’s chief financial officer also announced her eventual resignation.

Despite Hewitt’s assurances to KPMG staff that he had no plans to “reinsert himself” into the company’s management, the firm told the company’s board and management that it was concerned “integrity and tone at the top” could affect Liberty Tax’s internal control over financial reporting.

“Mr. Hewitt’s past and continued involvement in the company’s business and operations, including his continued interactions with franchisees and area developers of the company, has led (KPMG) to no longer be able to rely on management’s representations, and therefore has caused KPMG to be unwilling to be associated with the company’s consolidated financial statements,” the company wrote in its filing.

KPMG told the company that it had no reason to question to integrity of the current management team, but that the “structural arrangement by which Mr. Hewitt controls the company is the cause of KPMG’s concern.”

rows.title: Virginia Beach ordered 26 iPads to replace older ones. Then they sat in a closet for 6 months.
rows.prologue: The city's Economic Development department ordered nearly $17,000 worth of iPads and a laptop for staff and the Development Authority. No one ever paid for them, and they were ordered through an advertising agency instead of being put out to bid.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH
When iPads that the city’s Economic Development Department bought years earlier started to go on the fritz, the agency decided it was time for new ones.
But the devices were never distributed. Instead, they sat in a closet gathering dust for six months.
Why? The answer, it turned out, was a little murky and a little weird. But somebody clearly had some explaining to do.
The mystery of the abandoned Apple tablets began nearly a year ago.
In January, Scott Hall, the city’s business development coordinator, set out to order 26 iPads and one MacBook to replace older devices.

But before he did, Hall asked his boss, Warren Harris, in a February email if it was OK to order them through Otto, an advertising agency that does marketing for the city. Harris, the director of economic development, replied “Yes.”

In emails, Hall said the Virginia Beach Development Authority – made up of 11 members appointed by the City Council – would foot the bill. The independent agency tries to lure new businesses to the area to add jobs and increase the city’s tax base.
The older iPads had been acquired in the same way, Hall said. The department orders through Otto because the marketing agency loads proprietary software onto the devices, Harris said.
Diane Lingoni, production director for Otto, said her company didn’t do that before giving the tablets to the city in March.
In April, the Development Authority voted unanimously to spend up to $17,500 to buy the iPads and laptop.
The problem with this plan? City departments are supposed to get three bids before buying computers.

After learning about the iPads, The Virginian-Pilot filed a Freedom of Information Act request to find out how they were acquired. On Sept. 15, Harris wrote a memo explaining the situation to the city manager’s office .
He said his department did not follow the law on procurement that lays out how a city must go about buying items.

“I am writing to make you aware of an unfortunate mistake involving the purchase of a number of replacement computers that was inconsistent with the city’s IT procurement policy and the state’s procurement act,” Harris wrote. “I will make sure we receive retraining on the City’s procurement processes and develop a small purchase policy for the Virginia Beach Development Authority so this type of error does not happen again.”
In his letter to Deputy City Manager Ron Williams, Harris said the department kept the iPads and Macbook, but he also acknowledged that they were never paid for.
Otto sent an invoice to Economic Development for “platform presentation tools” – not iPads or a computer.
Emails also show that the city delayed payment, causing employees at Otto to worry.
“Please note the past due invoices on the attached statement,” Lingoni wrote on May 24. “My bookkeeper is seriously on my back about this, can you give me a payment status today?”
In a follow-up email, Lingoni said, “I think it’s mainly the iPads she’s worried about.”
It wasn’t until late September that Hall gave the devices back to Otto – without ever paying for them. He said the iPads were not returned sooner because he had “been on the road a lot.”
So what’s the vendor’s plan for them?
Lingoni told The Pilot in an email that Otto planned to sell the tablets through a third-party vendor. And she’s not even going to ask the city to pay for them.

Harris said Development Authority members and his staff use iPads for various reasons: to save money on printing costs, and to access an app that maps out the city, which is useful for businesses that are considering moving to Virginia Beach.

Most of the Development Authority members have had iPads since 2013. Even the board’s engineering consultant, Randy Royal, and a manager of a sister city’s office in Olongapo City, Philippines, were provided iPads.
Royal, of Kimley-Horn and Associates, said that a city-issued iPad makes his job easier, but lately many of them have been experiencing technical difficulties.
“Mine is in the shop, as are a lot of them,” Royal said.
Dot Wood, chairwoman of the Development Authority, said she was unaware of the purchasing issue with the iPads, but said she knew Economic Development had planned to buy new ones.
She said her city-owned iPad no longer works, but she prefers looking at paper documents anyway.

rows.title: Ancient practice of yoga could be answer to work stress | Expert column
rows.prologue: Yoga’s health benefits are well documented.
content: Rising in your career is challenging work. What if the answer to the associated stress and anxiety you feel comes from an ancient practice?

Yoga goes back to 3000 B.C. By some estimates, more than four million people practice yoga in the United States alone. As the baby boom generation ages, it’s likely these numbers will increase dramatically.
While yoga exercises can be quite vigorous, among the more than many 1,000 different poses, there is something for everyone.

Dancers can practice yoga to increase their energy and to improve their stamina. Executives can use it to stay calm and balanced in a hectic environment. Athletes can use it to improve performance or recover more quickly from an injury.
The idea of yoga is to awaken the mind, feed the body and rekindle the spirit.

You may have visions of people practicing yoga for hours on end (in weird body configurations). Yet, the masters tell us, the 10 to 15 minutes a day of basic yoga exercises can work wonders. People who practice yoga for at least 1 hour a week report they feel more relaxed at work, concentrate better, have a healthy appetite, have better sex and sleep more soundly.

Yoga’s health benefits are well documented. Some hospitals use it as an integral part of their program for heart attack survivors. In one study, people with serious heart disease had significant reductions in chest pains in less than two weeks. In less than 12 months, some members of the test group were able to reduce the amount of arterial blockage.

As with many stress reducing techniques, one starts a yoga exercise with a strategic pause. You sit back, take slow deep breaths and become relaxed. The variety of poses, postures and stresses help to keep the body limber. The slowly controlled moves in combination with breathing help keep the mind calm.

The kind of yoga you might do at a fitness club or health center is typically 60 or 90 minutes. The first 10 or 15 minutes take you through a series of breathing exercises with the primary goal of having you forget about your surroundings.

Thereafter, you might engage in 25 or 30 minutes of various sitting poses, each of which stretch and strengthen muscles. In the next 25- or 30-minute section, the typical class would move onto standing postures.
Yoga is not a quick fix; you have to practice it for a period of time before you can reap its benefits, however, you may find you feel so good afterword you’re hooked!

Jeff Davidson is principal of Breathing Space Institute in Raleigh, N.C. He offers keynote presentations and workshops on work-life balance. For more information, visit breathingspace.com or email jeff@breathingspace.com.

rows.title: No Blue Angels? No problem. Air Force's Thunderbirds to perform in Va. Beach in 2019
rows.prologue: The Air Force's elite flight demonstration team will be making a rare appearance at Naval Air Station Oceana's air show in 2019.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH
The Air Force’s Thunderbirds are coming to Virginia Beach.
The elite flight demonstration team will make a rare appearance at Naval Air Station Oceana’s air show in 2019.

The Navy said earlier this month that its premier flight demonstration team, the Blue Angels, would not perform at Oceana that year like it typically does. The Blue Angels fly the F/A-18 Hornet and many of the pilots and crew members have been stationed at Oceana at some point in their careers. But the Blue Angels will be in California at the time of the Oceana air show.
The Thunderbirds last appeared in Hampton Roads in 2016 for an air show at Langley Air Force Base in Hampton.
The Thunderbirds fly the F-16 Fighting Falcon and typically perform about 40 maneuvers during a demonstration, which lasts about 75 minutes.
They’re based at Nellis Air Force Base, Nev., and ultimately report to Air Combat Command at Langley .
The Air Force says the Thunderbirds can be combat-ready in 72 hours if needed .

rows.title: Split-funded retirement plans help reduce tax bite | Expert column
rows.tagline: Brent Saba is president of Allegiant Business Advisors. He can be reached at 843-405-2612 or at bsaba@allegiantbusinessadvisors.com.
content: For many highly compensated owners of professional practices or small businesses there is often frustration around the ability to replace income in retirement. While 401(k)s can help shelter compensation from taxes, the plans must follow federal limits for annual pretax contributions: $18,000 in 2017 for those under age 50 and $24,000 for those above.
These participant contribution limits combined with employer additions equal up to $54,000 total pretax contribution for those under age 50 and $60,000 for those above.

While this may seem like a nice chunk of change to sock away each year (and it is), for many business owners, the ability to replace income in retirement still falls short. The result is a significant “income replacement gap” in retirement.

In contrast, participants in split-funded plans, which have defined benefits, need not adhere to any government-set maximums for their annual pretax contributions. Instead, maximum pretax contributions are calculated for each participant based on age and earnings, and according to a preset targeted return on the plan’s assets.

What does that mean for a client who owns a professional practice or small business? With a cash-balance plan, an older, highly compensated practice-owning doctor, lawyer or business owner can park more than $250,000 a year in the pretax account — even as the costs of sponsoring and administering the plan for employees remain below those of a 401(k) plan.
Let’s look at an example of how a split-funded plan plays out.

A husband and wife (John, 63 and Rachel, 62) have a successful business that employs 14, including a son and daughter (ages 36 and 38). The clients and the children have been making maximum contributions to a 401(k)/profit-sharing plan.

Recently, the clients have begun discussing retiring in five years and passing the company to the son and daughter. Additionally, the need for increased income tax deduction was raised by the client’s CPA.

While the clients were eager to retire, they realized they had taken much of the company profits and invested it back into the business. Furthermore, they had depleted much of their savings by funding the educations for their children.
The owners desired to contribute about $600,000 per year, pre-tax, for the next five years, to a custom pension plan.

The plan needed to address three concerns: quickly accumulate retirement income; contributions had to be income tax deductible; and the plan needed to include life insurance as one of the assets in order to protect the wealth transfer. If the three concerns could be addressed, the company could pass to the children effectively and the clients would have sufficient income for retirement.
The client’s team of advisors worked to design the following:
• Total 401(k) for John and Rachel: $48,000
• Total split-funded defined benefit for John and Rachel: $550,000
• Required contribution for the employees: $43,000
• Total company tax deductible contribution: $641,000
In a 45 percent tax bracket, the $641,000 represented a tax savings of about $289,000 with John and Rachel realizing about 94 percent of the contribution for them.

In this scenario, the John and Rachel could contribute a much higher amount on a fully deductible basis thereby securing their need for income replacement in retirement as well as creating a successful transfer to children. Furthermore, their long-time, loyal employees benefited by receiving an annual contribution in addition to any previous qualified plan contributions.
Brent Saba is president of Allegiant Business Advisors. He can be reached at 843-405-2612 or at bsaba@allegiantbusinessadvisors.com.

rows.title: Republican E.W. Jackson announces U.S. Senate bid, hoping to unseat Tim Kaine
rows.prologue: Jackson, a Chesapeake minister, is the fourth Republican to announce a run.
rows.byline:
By Bill Bartel and Margaret Matray
The Virginian-Pilot
content: CHESAPEAKE
Chesapeake minister E.W. Jackson said Monday he will seek the Republican nomination to run against Democratic U.S. Sen. Tim Kaine.
“It’s time to believe in America again. It’s time to believe in Virginia again,” Jackson said while announcing his candidacy at the Chesapeake Golf Club. “It’s time to believe in almighty God again.”
Jackson is the fourth Republican to announce plans to run against Kaine, who is seeking a second six-year term in 2018.

The other Republicans in the race are Del. Nick Freitas of Culpepper; Prince William County Board Chairman Corey Stewart, who unsuccessfully sought the GOP nod in this year’s gubernatorial election; and Ivan Raiklin, an Army veteran, lawyer and investor from Fairfax County.
On Monday, Jackson said he stands with President Donald Trump on his agenda and desire to “drain the swamp.”

He said he would fight to make sure “the forgotten Americans” – including blacks and coal miners who lost jobs – are “remembered again.” He said he has a vision for ending the cycle of poverty and crime in cities, by rebuilding families.
“Together, we’re going to bring America back,” Jackson said.
Jackson is making his third bid for statewide office. In 2013, he was the GOP candidate for lieutenant governor and lost to Ralph Northam, then a Democratic state senator.
In 2012, he finished last in a four-person primary to pick the GOP’s U.S. Senate candidate. The winner was former Gov. George Allen, who lost in the general election to Kaine.

Jackson operates The Called Church, a ministry in Chesapeake. He moved to Hampton Roads in 1998 and was affiliated with Pat Robertson’s Christian Coalition, where he worked on political outreach aimed at black voters.
He has a law degree from Harvard University and an undergraduate degree from the University of Massachusetts.
Known for his impassioned rhetoric, he’s often spoken at Tea Party rallies and was a frequent critic of President Barack Obama.

He’s argued that the United States is a Christian nation and has denounced same-sex marriage. In recent months, he’s been critical of professional athletes who dropped to one knee during the national anthem to protest racial discrimination, saying they’re showing “hatred for our country.”

rows.title: Big, Beautiful Blooms
rows.prologue: Find floral inspiration for your big day with these 6 new wedding flower trends
content: Flowers are big on your list for bringing together your wedding day vision. But it can be hard to find exactly what you want and what will pair perfectly with your overall wedding theme. If going the trendy route is a priority, check out these tips from industry experts.
Greenery Galore

As Pantone's color of the year, Greenery is more popular than in years past, says Joe Rogers, founder and creative director of the Boston-based Contagious Events. “There have always been clients who have looked at greenery as a cheaper alternative to florals, but now we're seeing couples who are spending the money for more lavish and hearty greenery arrangements,” Rogers says.

Think eucalyptus, ferns, tropical leaves and bright green pods, berries and moss as décor with a spattering of brightly colored flowers, recommends Anastasia Stevenson, floral and event designer. Stevenson says greenery garlands can make a dramatic focal point just about anywhere, including on tables, chair backs, arches and trees.

“Centerpieces are incorporating lanterns filled with flowers and fairy lights, elevated compote glass vases with large, unstructured greenery focused designs or streamlined modern, simpler designs in popular brass terrariums with succulents, flowers and sand,” she adds.
Gushing Gold

Gold has a place too. “There will always be a place for the classics like white and blush, but there's definitely a rise in couples who are opting for bright, bold colors and unique blooms,” Rogers says.

Janel Bailey-Keen, executive creative director for Vivid Expressions in Norfolk, Virginia, agrees, noting that a trending metallic is rose gold. As a luscious, luxurious and romantic tone, Bailey-Keen says rose gold is slightly more muted and antique in feel than other golds, and complements warmer colors like pinks, reds, orange and reddish purples. “The rose tone also pairs well with greens and other neutrals,” Bailey-Keen notes.
Woodland Wonderland
As many ceremonies move to the outdoors, Stevenson says they embrace overall themes of woodland wonderland. “Think tons of wild and free style florals with greenery as the focus,” she says.

Common arrangements are handcrafted wooden arches adorned with assorted greenery and unique blooms like King Protea, pods mixed with peonies and garden roses, floral chandeliers and floral adorned lanterns in trees.

Rose petal aisles outdoors are also popular, Stevenson says. “Brides are mixing it up by having petals in circles and other designs instead of the traditional more structured line down the middle of the aisle,” she says.
Wearable Florals
To keep the woodland feel alive, brides are opting for wearable floral. “If not bohemian style crowns, then other types of floral headpieces,” says Rogers.

They are also incorporating more florals into their bridal party, such as flowers woven into bridesmaid's updos and braids. “This trend has become so popular because it has a stunning effect with little effort and a low impact on their budget,” says Stevenson.
Cascading Bouquets

Lush, billowing and cascading hand-tied bouquets are on the rise, according to Bailey-Keen. However, she cautions: “Be sure to work with a florist who can create an impressive bouquet, but scale it to be proportional – we've see a lot of enormous bouquets that are so large they seem to carry the bride and camouflage her and her gown,” Bailey-Keen says.
Masculine Bouts

Grooms are ditching traditional boutonnieres for simple pocket squares, says Rogers. “What I love (and predict could be popular in the future) are box bouts – best described as floral pocket squares," he says.
Stevenson points out that floral boutonnieres are also becoming more fun and masculine, “with grooms forgoing the old single rose tradition.”

rows.title: Air Force sexual misconduct cases mishandled, according to reports
rows.prologue: CBS' Norah O'Donnell and Jennifer Janisch were in the midst of a six-month investigation into sexual assault cases at the U.S. Air Force Academy when news of Charlie Rose came out.
content: NEW YORK

One reason for the steeliness in Norah O'Donnell's demeanor the morning after the sexual misconduct accusations against former "CBS This Morning" co-anchor Charlie Rose were revealed became apparent on Monday.

She and her colleague, producer Jennifer Janisch, were in the midst of a six-month investigation into sexual assault cases at the U.S. Air Force Academy. Their first report, saying that more than a dozen current and former Air Force cadets believe their cases had been mishandled and that they faced retaliation, aired Monday on "CBS This Morning."
Two current and two former cadets talked to O'Donnell on the broadcast about their experiences.

When "CBS This Morning" reported on Rose the morning of Nov. 21, O'Donnell spoke sternly about what had been learned about their colleague. There's no excuse, she said. "This has to end. This behavior is wrong. Period," she said. Rose was fired hours later.

"When I said women cannot achieve full equality in the workforce until there is a reckoning and a taking of responsibility, that line and the sternness with which I delivered it, was impacted because of what I witnessed at the Air Force academy," O'Donnell said.

While the Department of Defense has encouraged victims of abuse in the military to report their stories, O'Donnell said that attitude hasn't fully filtered down, and that some women have been ostracized or retaliated against for talking about it.

"That, to me, is egregious and unacceptable and it is ruining what could be fine military careers," said O'Donnell, whose father served in the military for 30 years and whose sister is in the Army. One of the former cadets who spoke to CBS left the academy while her alleged harasser graduated.
Similar stories inspired Janisch, who said she wanted to look into the impact of sexual misconduct on women away from high-profile careers like the media and entertainment.
The current cadets had their identities obscured during the CBS interview because they were not permitted to speak to the press.

"It was incredibly brave of them to not only share their stories on the phone, but to leave the campus and risk their military careers to sit down with us to shine a light on what they believe is a systemic problem at the U.S. Air Force Academy," O'Donnell said.

rows.title: Figure out where you are in your entrepreneurial life cycle | Expert column
rows.prologue: Those four cycles have easy-to-remember names: Growers, Gliders, Speed-bumpers and Exiters.
rows.tagline: Ami Kassar is founder and chief executive officer of Multifunding LLC and author of the forthcoming book "The Growth Dilemma." Visit Multifunding.com to learn more.
content: Just as we experience spring, summer, fall and winter each year, there are a similar number of cycles for entrepreneurs. It’s important to understand into which cycle you presently fit, because it determines how you approach growth, financial options and risk.
So, what are those four cycles?
Here are some easy-to-remember names: Growers, Gliders, Speed-bumpers and Exiters.
Consider the case of John, a man in his early 60s whose software company has coasted along for years. The business is growing steadily, although at a much slower pace than 20 years ago.

John’s financially set for life and wants to enjoy retirement. Although there’s no immediate hurry, he’s looking to cash out from his company, which is now largely in the hands of his capable daughter.
As you might guess, John is an Exiter.

At a social function, John strikes up a conversation with a husband-and-wife team named Jason and Tara who run a fledgling software company of their own, although they aren’t direct competitors. Jason and Tara have just won a significant contract and their products are receiving good reviews, but they need capital to meet their demands.
These classic Growers ask John for advice, figuring (correctly) he’s seen it all. So what does John tell them?
An aggressive businessman all his life, John essentially tells Jason and Tara to be bold – which is the only way to successfully get through each individual entrepreneurial cycle.
GROWERS

A Grower is the type of entrepreneur typically depicted in film, on television, in books and all other forms of media. These are the businesspeople looking to expand their operations, often rapidly. They generally have a healthy appetite for assuming risk and are loaded with self-confidence.

John tests Jason and Tara by asking them what they’d do if they received a $1 million gift. Would they invest all (or most) of that money directly into their business or would they hold on to it, essentially saving it for a rainy day?
John’s happy to hear his newfound friends didn’t hesitate before saying they were confident in their business and figured investing the money would go a long way toward solving their growth issues.

While John is speaking, his audience grows, enthralled by the wisdom he’s imparting. One of the listeners is a long-time friend named Mary whose small custom-framing chain of stores is stable and profitable. She is a Glider.
GLIDERS
Mary tells the group she’s reached a happy point where she’s making a solid amount of money, expects her business to remain sound and is loath to wreck a good thing.
John’s been somewhat of a mentor to Mary over the years, so he poses the same hypothetical $1 million gift question he asked Jason and Tara.

That led Mary to waffle a bit. She first said she would place a significant chunk of that gift into mutual funds, happy with a smaller return, but still available to be used if need be. After more thought, she decided to put about 75 percent in her business because she realized she was already generating a higher return than what a mutual fund offered.

John approved, noting that keeping a business on an even keel is never a bad thing, especially for someone like Mary, who is beginning to consider retirement options. He also pointed out that since her business was doing well, there’d be no shortage of palatable financial options available if the need arose.

The conversation lurches in a different direction, however, when a frazzled-looking entrepreneur joins the discussion. That would be Derek, the founder of an online sporting goods store. Derek’s business was growing at a double-digit rate, but he overestimated his market and is now stuck with a warehouse full of unsold goods – not to mention his bank wants to pull its line of credit and is demanding repayment.
Derek, a textbook Speed-bumper, asks John what he should do.
SPEED-BUMPERS
John points out that a little rain falls on most people’s lives at some point and entrepreneurs aren’t immune.
Again, he brings up the hypothetical $1 million gift.

It doesn’t take long for Derek to gain clarity when he says he would plunk most or the entire hypothetical $1 million gift into his business. While some non-entrepreneurs might consider that foolish, Derek realizes that for any business to succeed, it requires the stomach for at least some risk along with overriding confidence. By stepping back, he realizes his company and business model are viable and will need some fine tuning.

John cautions that challenges might lie ahead because some financial options will be closed to him. And the options that will be open may carry a greater risk (or interest rate) or even the possibility of surrendering some equity.
Having provided his sage advice to the others, the group of entrepreneurs questions John about his plans.
EXITERS
John replies that even the most-fervent entrepreneur will walk away at some point. The reason doesn’t really matter.
The group then turns the tables on John and asks him what he’d do with the hypothetical $1 million gift.
Not surprisingly, he said, he decides he’d invest half of it in mutual funds, but put the rest back into the business, noting it would help his successor daughter.

John points out succession planning is important, but too many businesses either overlook it or give it short shrift. After all, who wants to be thinking about the distant future when the thrill of running a business still looms?

He notes eventually that day comes, however, and transitioning power is a delicate process, especially when you consider your legacy, not to mention tax concerns, heirs and dozens of other things that often aren’t considered.
No matter what cycle they’re in, entrepreneurs are a fascinating breed; they represent much of what makes the American business world so great.
That said, entrepreneurs don’t know everything and tend to look at the big picture and forgo some of the fine details. That’s why they sometimes need outside help.
The key to providing that help is recognizing that no two businesses – and their financial situations – are alike and can’t be addressed with a rote game plan.
Ami Kassar is founder and chief executive officer of Multifunding LLC and author of the forthcoming book “The Growth Dilemma.” Visit Multifunding.com to learn more.

rows.title: Norfolk police make arrest in Norview double shooting, homicide
rows.prologue: Claude M. Smith was found in a car on Ivaloo Street.
content: NORFOLK
A sign warns troublemakers approaching a Norview house where two men were shot, one to death, Sunday morning.
“Due to price increase of ammo, Do not expect a warning shot.”
A shotgun, shells and fake buckshot holes next to the built-in thermometer punctuate the message.
The sound of children laughing and playing during recess cut against what happened the day before.

Norview Middle School is a stone’s throw and across a creek from the 1000 block of Ivaloo Street, where officers discovered 31-year-old Claude Milton Smith in a car suffering from gunshot wounds around 2 a.m. Sunday.
Paramedics took him to Sentara Norfolk General Hospital, where doctors pronounced him dead.
Police also discovered another man with a gunshot wound inside a house.
He, too, was taken to the hospital. His wounds were serious but not life-threatening.

On Monday night, police said they had arrested a suspect. Gary Lee Drew Jr., 25, was charged with one count each of second-degree murder and malicious wounding, and two counts use of a firearm in commission of felony. He was being held in Norfolk City Jail without bond
“Everyone is in shock,” neighbor Sean Hazzard said.
A 48-year-old man owns the house where the second man was found, records show.
But neighbor Adrienne Walsh said the owner hasn’t lived in the house for a while.
Hazzard said the man’s 44-year-old ex-wife does. Obviously distraught, she came to the house Sunday morning as detectives and officers swarmed the street, he said.
Walsh and Hazzard were sleeping when the shooting happened. Walsh said she’s a light sleeper, so it’s “really, really unusual” she didn’t wake up until police knocked on her door.
Neither recognized Smith’s name.
“It’s a big mystery,” Walsh said. “Normally, the only noise we have is the children from the middle school playing.”

Hazzard said wondering why gunfire erupted feet away from his home is unsettling. Was it an isolated incident between the two men that’s over and done with? Or is it part of something ongoing that may lead to more violence in the neighborhood?
“It’s 100 different options that could’ve happened,” he said.
Smith’s family could not be reached Monday.

Detectives are investigating his death as a homicide. They haven’t released any details about a shooter but are asking anyone with information about what happened to call the Norfolk Crime Line at 1-888-LOCK-U-UP.
Smith’s death is Norfolk’s 32nd homicide this year, including two police shootings.
Detectives have filed charges in 19 of them, although prosecutors later dropped charges in some of those cases.
Over the past decade, there was an average of about about 36 homicides at this point in the year.
Court records show Smith had several criminal convictions in Norfolk.
In 2006, he was convicted of maliciously shooting at a vehicle, threatening someone and having a gun as a felon .
On July 7, 2005, Smith told a woman from the backseat of a moving car that he was going to kill her after passing by her house twice before.
The woman suspected he was stalking her because his friends had shot her son recently.
A few minutes later, when the two ran into each other again and the woman flipped open her phone to call police, Smith threatened her again: “If you call, I’m going to blast you. I’m not playing.”
The woman noticed he had a rifle in his hand, court documents show.
As she drove around the corner, she heard a loud blast and saw sparks coming from the gun using the side mirror.
Police came and found a nickel-sized hole in the driver’s side of the car.
In 2011, he was convicted of having crack cocaine and assaulting law enforcement for elbowing a Norfolk police officer in the face.

rows.title: Yanni tour marking 25th anniversary of "Acropolis" is coming to Virginia Beach on May 9
keywords: sandler center for the performing arts
rows.prologue: Performer and composer Yanni is celebrating the 25th anniversary of his “Live at the Acropolis” concert with a world tour that will include a May 9 show at the Sandler Center.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH

Performer and composer Yanni is celebrating the 25th anniversary of his “Live at the Acropolis” concert with a world tour that will include a May 9 performance at the Sandler Center for the Performing Arts.
VIP and Fan Club pre-sale tickets will be available Wedesday at YNottix.com; tickets will go on sale Friday at the Sandler Center box office, online and at 877-YnotTix.
A deluxe package of remastered 5.1 sound and high-definition video of “Live At The Acropolis" will be released in 2018 to commemorate this anniversary.
Yanni's breakthrough album, "Live at the Acropolis" was recorded at the Herodes Atticus Theatre in Athens with the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra from London and released in 1994.

Featuring his blend of jazz, classical, soft rock and world music, the concert was made into a TV special that aired in on PBS. Yanni has more than 40 platinum and gold albums and has sold more than 25 million albums.

rows.title: Want to name the Virginia Zoo's new lion cub? It'll cost you $1.
rows.prologue: Starting today, participants who want to name The Virginia Zoo's newest lion cub can submit their idea by until noon on Dec. 22.
content: NORFOLK
With six weeks of of life under its belt, the Virginia Zoo’s newest lion cub is ready for a name.
Starting today, those with thoughts on that matter can submit their name suggestions VirginiaZoo.org/lion-cub-naming. Voting ends at noon Dec. 22.

It’ll cost $1 to submit each idea. The zoo will donate all the money from the naming contest to the Pride Lion Conservation Alliance, which works to protect African lions in Kenya, Tanzania, Mozambique and Zambia.
The cub’s new name will be announced Christmas morning.
Zola, the zoo’s 13-year-old lioness, gave birth to the male cub Oct. 28. It likes to chase its mom’s tail and climb in and out of its nest box, the zoo said in a news release.
The zoo last held a naming contest this summer for a baby giraffe, who is now called Iggy. The name was picked from over 3,000 suggestions.

rows.title: Holiday gift drive will benefit homeless youth living at Oceanfront
rows.prologue: A year ago, the 20-year-old single mother didn't have a job and she was living with her boyfriend. When she needed a double stroller and car seats for her 3-year-old and newborn, she wasn't sure where to turn. Enter Betsy Hardy, who is organizing her second gift drive.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH
A year ago, the 20-year-old single mother didn’t have a job and was living with her boyfriend.
When she needed a double stroller and car seats for her 3-year-old and newborn, she wasn’t sure where to turn.

Enter Betsy Hardy, who organized a gift drive for the nonprofit StandUp for Kids last year. Her hook? A human-sized nest where people could pluck a tag with a name on it and drop off gifts and stockings. More than 50 homeless and at-risk children and young adults received presents through the drive – including Totianna, who got what she needed for her children. She asked that her last name not be published.

Hardy is at it again this year with a big, cardboard snowflake displayed in the lobby of a bank building at the eastern end of Interstate 264 at the Oceanfront. People can pick up tags and deliver gifts through Friday.
She chose StandUp for Kids because it helps children at the Oceanfront, where Hardy owns a business.
StandUp For Kids was founded in 1990 in San Diego. The nonprofit outreach program, now in 17 cities, provides food, clothing and mentors for homeless people 24 years old and younger.

The local chapter has a drop-in center in the resort area at the Oceanfront. It’s an upstairs room of a building a block from Atlantic Avenue. At the top of the stairs, there’s a sign-in sheet on a clipboard and a volunteer greeter. There are posters on the walls and games to play.
The young men and women who come to the Crow’s Nest are homeless. Some are housed in shelters. Some sleep in tents in the woods. Others stay with friends, or what Mark Stevens calls couch-surfing.
Stevens has been advocating for local children for nine years. He’s executive director of the Hampton Roads StandUp for Kids chapter.
Twelve volunteers help Stevens. They serve dinner three nights a week as well as collect and distribute clothing, backpacks, diapers and toiletries.
They try to provide guidance like a parent would, Stevens said. They help find more permanent housing and jobs.
StandUp for Kids has provided bus passes and, sometimes, hotel rooms. The organization relies on donations.
Totianna, who now lives in a shelter for at-risk women, may soon move into an apartment with her sons, who are now 4 and 1.
She credits StandUp for Kids with helping her.
“If it wasn’t for this place, I’d be in a tough situation,” she said.

Before a volunteer at StandUp for Kids took Totianna under her wing, she had almost given up hope. She was having problems at home and was trying to mother a toddler. She thought about dropping out of high school, she said.
With encouragement from StandUp for Kids, Totianna graduated from the Renaissance Academy last year, and will start college in January.
StandUp for Kids has been like a family for her.
“I see that they care,” she said. “It makes me feel like I’m loved.”

rows.title: Local TV segments look at cooking, fun and the arts in Hampton Roads
content: Are you hungry after all that Christmas shopping? You’ve come to the right place.
Welcome to “The 5-Minute Chef,” a feature airing on two locally produced television shows – “Coast Live” on WTKR weekdays at 10 a.m and “Kickin’ It in the 757” on WGNT Sundays at 8:30 a.m.

On a recent broadcast of “Coast Live,” British-born Alvin W. Williams, owner of and executive chef at the Cobalt Grille in Virginia Beach, whipped up Sauteed Shrimp and Scallops Risotto in three minutes and 31 seconds.
Williams’ tip of the day: Always serve warm food on a warm plate.
About a year ago Kevin Neff created “Kickin’ It in the 757” with co-producer Mike Martine. The show looks at the places in Hampton Roads where we live, work, dine and play.
Neff refers to his show as “edu-tainment.”
“We wanted to do something unique, a kind of entertainment and news-style TV magazine show that encourages people to get out and explore what we have here, including what’s new,” he said.

Neff appeared in a report on indoor skydiving at iFly Virginia Beach, but in most interviews he stays in the background, allowing the folks on camera to talk without interruption – such as when developer Gerald Divaris extolled the virtues of Town Center in Virginia Beach. Is Town Center downtown or uptown Virginia Beach? Divaris gives his opinion in the series’ ninth episode, which is available at kickinitinthe757.com.
Here’s a sample of Neff’s “edu-tainment” from recent episodes of “Kickin’ It ,” seen on Channel 27 as well as on Verizon FIOS, the Dish Network, DirecTV and local cable:

• More than 200,000 people live within five miles of Town Center.
  • Janeeda begins her performance of classic belly dancing at 8 p.m. Saturdays at Ammos Authentic Greek Cuisine restaurant at Chambord Commons in Virginia Beach.
  • A Julius Erving Virginia Squires jersey, No. 32, from the era of the late, great American Basketball Association goes for $120 at the Williamsburg Antique Mall.

Neff charges a fee to produce some segments , but resists calling the 30-minute show an infomercial because it has newsy moments that have nothing to do with trendy restaurants or chic boutiques. He recently introduced viewers to some F-18 pilots, the Gladiators of VFA-106 at the 2017 NAS Oceana Air Show, and highlighted the good work done by the Navy Gold Star Program.
Local arts on local TV

A second season of “Curate” on WHRO is introducing Hampton Roads to local creative minds and artists, like Spencer Tinkham of Norfolk, a professional wood sculptor who calls himself a creative carver.
“Curate” airs Fridays at 8:30 p.m. on WHRO and in a digital version (“Curate 757”) every Wednesday on Facebook and YouTube. Heather Mazzoni and Jason Kypros are the co-hosts.

“We’re excited to highlight the inspiring work and creations found in Eastern Virginia and beyond,” Mazzoni said. WHRO Public Media hails the series as a showcase for the art scene (painting, sculpture, photography and the spoken word) in our own backyard and across America.

Of sculpting birds, fish and duck decoys, the 25-year-old Tinkham said: “Inspiration is all around me.” He searches everywhere for his raw materials, including the aged wood he finds on the shores of rivers and the ocean and in marshes.
The latest episode, “When Art Reflects Mortality,” featured Norfolk photographer John Wadsworth and his exhibition “The Art of Dying.”

It included Amanda Outcalt, a painter, printmaker and metalsmith whose work explores the relationship of individual and community. One of her paintings was selected as the commemorative poster for the 2010 Boardwalk Art Show by the Virginia Museum of Contemporary Art.

Other segments looked at the fantasy coffins of West Ghana; Connie Frisbee Houde, a humanitarian photojournalist based in Albany, N.Y.; and Gary Hovey, an artist from rural Ohio who uses stainless steel flatware to make wildlife sculptures.
To learn more about “Curate,” visit whro.org/curate.

rows.title: Dying artist donates heart painting to Norfolk General
rows.prologue: "I'm dying," Norfolk artist Norman Goodwin said in the midst of an colorful conversation about his life. "I've been fighting Lymphoma and throat cancer. And the chemo and radiation had me in such a weak state that I fell and broke my hip and knee. The pain from the knee has been worse than the cancer. And I used to be such a great dancer."
content: NORFOLK
Norman Goodwin sat casually in an orange chair, staring out the window of his home off Wayne Creek.
Outside it was gray, cold and dreary, but the famed Norfolk artist was cozy in a blue robe and printed silk ascot.
Talking colorfully about his life, he wore his heart on his sleeve.

“I’m dying,” the 72-year-old said. “I’ve been fighting lymphoma and throat cancer. And the chemo and radiation had me in such a weak state that I fell and broke my hip and knee. The pain from the knee has been worse than the cancer.
“And I used to be such a great dancer.”

He’s still a great artist, whose works can be found in a variety of museums and private collections and, now, at Sentara Norfolk General Heart Hospital. One of his 6-foot by 6-foot heart paintings boldly stands out high on a wall in the lobby.
The heart is typical of Goodwin’s “abstract expressionist” style. He gave it to the hospital because he didn’t want it to be lost in obscurity.

“When I realized I was going to die, I figured these hearts should be available for people to see,” said Goodwin, who said he spent 42 years teaching art at Old Dominion University and helped found d’Art Center in Norfolk.
Originally, his 22 heart paintings were part of a 1988 museum show. He said he always wanted to give this one to the hospital – years ago it was the hospital’s logo.

“This heart was the symbol of our program,” said Audrey Douglas Cooke, vice president of patient care services. Another of Goodwin’s paintings is destined for a heart hospital in Greenville, N.C.; Goodwin’s father was from nearby Edenton.

Goodwin still paints from time to time, but says he’s had to scale back on the size of his works because of his lack of mobility. He uses a walker to get around his home, but can’t make it to his studio in the back of the house because of the steps.

“I’ve basically been painting lying down in bed,” he said, crossing his legs and folding his hands on his knee. “I try to draw or paint almost every day. But I paint best when I’m in love or happy. And I haven’t been happy for two years, and I’m alone these days.”
Goodwin grew up in Norfolk and graduated from William and Mary before earning his doctorate in 20th century American art.
“Oh, honey ... I was such a hell-raiser in college,” he said, waiving his hands over his head. “And an impertinent twit at the same time.”

While in New York, he said, he took up acting and appeared in several Broadway and off-Broadway productions before returning to Norfolk to pursue a career in art. When his father died, he moved into the house his dad built to “store all the antiques he hated” and to take care of his mother.
“She was my best friend in the world,” he said.

These days, Goodwin sits in the cluttered world of the house’s living room, often waiting for his physical therapist. If there is one thing he misses at this stage in his life, it’s working with his students.
“I shared my life and my work with them,” he said, pulling out of a bag a painting he planned to give to a former student as a Christmas present. “Oh, honey ... we’ve had some marvelous times.”

rows.title: A developer wants rent-controlled apartments in Portsmouth, but council members are skeptical
rows.prologue: Mayor John Rowe says residents wonder: “Why don’t we have a grocery store downtown?’”
content: PORTSMOUTH
An Ohio-based developer wants to put 59 rent-controlled apartments in an empty downtown lot, but it’ll have to convince skeptical City Council members who would rather lure a grocer there.

Woda Group has submitted a plan to the city for a 76,000-square-foot, four-story building at 818 County Street, just south of Effingham and High streets. Woda hopes to rent out about 5,000 square feet of retail space on the first floor.

But a majority of City Council members seem unconvinced by the idea – which was raised last month by the Portsmouth Redevelopment and Housing Authority board – and they will ultimately decide whether to give Woda the OK to build.

“It would be great if we could meet the demand for retail grocery shopping,” Mayor John Rowe said, pointing to a nearby mixed-use development that has apparently struggled to bring commercial tenants to fill its first floor. “I don’t think we need to jump at the first development idea that comes along. I think we need to get what’s best for the community, and I hear this very frequently: ‘Why don’t we have a grocery store downtown?’ ”

At least three others on the seven-member council – Bill Moody, Nathan Clark and Elizabeth Psimas – seemed to agree at a Nov. 27 work session where the group discussed the proposal with the housing authority board. The plan will first go before the city’s Planning Commission, which will make a recommendation to the City Council.
“It’s absolutely foolish to put low-income housing on one of the most heavily traveled parcels of commercial property in our city,” Moody said. “We have our share of low-income housing now.”

Housing authority Executive Director Ed Bland said Woda has applied for a tax credit from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, which would require the developer to cap rents. The goal, he said, is to rent out apartments to people who earn about $45,000 per year.
At last month’s meeting, Economic Development Director Robert Moore suggested to council members that a grocer has shown interest in the plot.
“At this point, we have had interest from a number of different commercial entities,” Moore said. “A grocery store here downtown is certainly an option.”
Moore declined to speak with The Virginian-Pilot about the city’s development efforts, and attempts to reach Woda were unsuccessful.

Some housing authority board members said they’re frustrated that the land has been vacant for decades, and Alisa Winston, the authority’s deputy executive director, told the City Council that the the authority had signed a letter of intent with Woda.

The authority refused to release the letter this week, citing an exemption to the state’s Freedom of Information Act that allows government officials to withhold information “relating to the negotiation and award of a specific contract where competition or bargaining is involved and where the release of such information would adversely affect the bargaining position or negotiating strategy of the public body.”
The housing authority has owned the parcel since 1989, according to public records.

Councilman Mark Whitaker said it’s too early for his colleagues to discuss the proposed apartment building, and he accused some of trying to manipulate the housing authority board, which is appointed by the council.

“There appears to be an inequity in that we have no problem putting high-end apartments downtown, but now when it comes to workforce housing, all of a sudden we have an issue with it,” Whitaker said. “Underneath all of this, some (council members) have an issue with the type of residents that may be living in that area. And to me, I thought that we ought to try to service all of our citizens when it comes to housing needs.”

rows.title: Soybean harvest on track for third high-yield year running
rows.prologue: Survey statistics show that for at least the third year running, growers in most areas of Virginia are expecting good quality, high yield crops. That general pattern has held true locally.
content: Late fall is a season of high hope. That may be even more true for local farmers: In fields all over southeastern Virginia, it’s begun to look a lot like soybean harvest.

And the 2017 harvest is expected to be a strong one. Survey statistics show that for at least the third year running, growers in most areas of Virginia are expecting good quality, high yield crops. That general pattern has held true locally.

“We’ve heard consistent yields just north of 50 [bushels per acre],” said Roy Flanagan, Virginia Beach’s agriculture extension agent. By the time the last harvests are brought in, he said, “I think we’ll be in upper 40s average.”
That compares favorably to the Beach’s average yield last year of 48 bushels per acre.

Flanagan said the Beach’s harvest is also progressing faster than usual. As of the last week of November, he estimated 70 percent of Virginia Beach’s beans were already in. In a typical year, harvest extends into mid-December.

Soybeans have been coming in so fast, with so little break between loads, that Flanagan said the two granaries Beach growers usually use ran into an unusual glitch: too much stock and not enough storage.
Adjustments to trucking schedules fixed the problem, Flanagan said, and Beach soybean work has since continued in the same positive direction.
“As far as I’m concerned it didn’t hurt anybody,” Flanagan said. “Just slowed progress for a minute.”

Flanagan attributes both high yield and the relative speed of this year’s harvest to nearly two weeks without significant rain – what Flanagan called “an unprecedented stretch of good harvesting conditions.” It added up to no delays between ready-to-cut fields, waiting for soils to dry out again, just a solid stream of harvest.

For Suffolk and Western Tidewater farmers, too, the late-season weather has smiled on soybeans. Virginia Cooperative Extension soybean specialist David Holshouser said many crops were started later than ideal because of soggy spring soils. While some of those late crops never quite recovered, others are looking very good now that harvest is near.
But despite those pockets of lesser results, Holshouser said the overall outlook for the 2017 soybean crop is still strong, with some areas showing remarkably good signs.
“We’re pretty excited about the yields this year,” Holshouser said.
Like Flanagan, Holshouser said weather is a big factor. But looking at soybeans from a whole-state perspective, he said, there’s a bigger story at work.
“Rainfall at the right time is almost always responsible for good yields, but improved management is also key,” Holshouser said.
Holshouser said a person outside of farming might see “good yield” and assume this means growers are achieving those numbers by pushing excessive fertilizers and pesticides into crops.

“But actually it’s just the opposite. We’re doing a lot more with less now,” Holshouser said. Looking at environmental quality measurements on a per-square-foot basis, he said, farming actually does better than average.

Holshouser said simply choosing the right seed for the land can account for as much as half of the increase in soybean yield year to year. And he gives at least as much credit to farmers themselves: A quality crop requires close monitoring, weighing every intervention decision and using proven techniques.

“The weather’s caused the really good yields this year, but we wouldn’t have realized that without good seed and good management,” Holshouser said. “The farmers are just doing a much better job growing beans than they did 10, even five years ago.”

rows.title: Crash involving school bus, motorcycle in Virginia Beach closes roads, 1 injured
rows.prologue: The roads between S. Independence Boulevard and S. Rosemont Road are closed in both directions after a crash between a school bus and a motorcycle, police said.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH
A school bus and a motorcycle were involved in a crash just after 6 a.m. on Lynnhaven Parkway near Rosemont Road Monday morning, police said.
The motorcycle driver was is being treated for serious injuries, police said. There were no children on the bus at the time of the crash and the bus driver is not injured, police said.
The roads near the crash, which was on the 1500 block of Lynnhaven Parkway and the 1400 block of Wendfield Drive, will be closed for several hours, police said.
The roads between S. Independence Boulevard and S. Rosemont Road are closed in both directions, police said.
